PETITION.TITLE: Chiropractic Services
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Chiropractic Services
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia shows :
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice and does nothing to reduce the high cost of health care in Australia.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beddall,Mr Cadman and Mr Hawker.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Self-Government
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in November 1978 more than sixty-two per cent of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory in a Referendum rejected the introduction of Territorial Government or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.

That until the findings of the Commonwealth Grants Commission Inquiry into Australian Capital Territory finances have been made public and there has been a Referendum of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory as to their attitude to Territorial or Local Government.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Government take no further action or legislation in respect of Territorial or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman and Mr Dobie.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornographic Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

That Regulations and an Ordinance before the Parliament amend the Customs ( Prohibited Imports) Regulation and the Customs (Cinematograph and Films) Regulations and supersedes the ACT Objectionable Publication Ordinance in such a manner as to be harmful to society by removing from existing Commonwealth Law-
The power to prevent the importation and sale of hard core pornography (X-rated videos) and publications which consistently incite the use of hard drugs;
The power to prevent the importation and sale of grossly obscene publications including those associated with blasphemy;
The power to require videos for non-commercial use to be registered by the Films Censorship Board before release from Customs.
Your Petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should disallow the new Regulations and Ordinance and ensure:
That the Attorney-General enforce existing laws;
That the Censors more appropriately reflect reasonable and responsible community attitudes;
That further measures be taken in association with the States to protect Australians, particularly women and children, from exploitation;
That, because of the importance of this issue to the whole community a conscience vote be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hunt and Mr Keating.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to:
Undermine civil liberties and religious freedom;
Entrench abortion funding and render liable to action Hospitals, Doctors and Nurses, who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations;
Deny to parents their rights to insist that the school ''community'' provide an environment condusive to the development, including moral development of their children.
Deny to parents their rights to have their children enjoy single-sex sporting activities for example, boys cricket team, boys football team, etc.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Parliament assembled: should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of all principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Airport at Scheyville, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That an airport in the north-western region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programs,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:
1. The Hawke Labor Government's retirement income policies are piecemeal, inconsistent and make no provision to encourage people to save towards their retirements, and
2. The Government's proposed assets test legislation, presently under re- examination, is iniquitous and, if enacted, its effects would be discriminatory.

2. Either institute a broad enquiry into Australia's retirement income and taxation system or wait the outcome of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare's work on this matter, and
3. Following the report of such a wide enquiry, institute a retirement income policy which is fair and equitable, that encourages self-provision and which will be non-discriminatory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Advertising of Alcohol
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the citizens of Queensland respectfully show:

DEBATE.TITLE: LOCAL GOVERNMENT (PERSONAL INCOME TAX SHARING) AMENDMENT BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 May, on motion by Mr Uren:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate was interrupted last night I was talking about the terms of reference for the membership of the committee that is to inquire into local government. Just to conclude the thoughts I have on that, I believe it is essential that that committee's terms of inquiry into local government should be widened to give the maximum possibility for a fuller inquiry in that regard. Proper constitutional recognition for local government will result only from such an inquiry and a determination by that committee that local government should be granted a percentage of Federal revenues appropriate to the responsibilities that it has assumed from the Federal government over a period. Having established that percentage, local government's participation would be on the basis of sharing in the government of the day's own economic and financial situation, raising or lowering according to the nation's own economic performance and ability to pay.

SPEECH.PARA: The unfortunate feature of personal income tax sharing has been the manner in which all States have been prepared to reduce their own subsidies and grants to local government, stepping away from their responsibilities as the Federal government has stepped in, thus placing local government in a position of even greater dependency on Commonwealth funding and of having to increase its own rate revenue. Local government sees that as adding the greatest pressure on its finance it has experienced in the time it has been in existence in Australia. Local government has to bear cost increases brought about by increases in fuel costs, bank transaction tax, registrations and licences while suffering decreases in State grants and not being appropriately funded by the Commonwealth . As a result, the 838 local government authorities around Australia are actually in a crisis situation.

In many instances local government itself has no further capacity to borrow in the light of the present crisis. Interest and redemptions are taking a greater and greater percentage of rate income at a time when there is no certainty in funding from either the Commonwealth or the States. Some State associations have examined this crisis situation of increasing Commonwealth and State costs and shrinking subsidy and grant revenue. I believe that many members of the Opposition who will be speaking in this debate will be able to give personal experience of how their States have withdrawn finances at a time when Commonwealth finances have been increasing. Examples of this can be given. I just want to give an example concerning my own State of Queensland and I believe the situation in Queensland probably is the same as that throughout all the States.

The State local government association concerned compared revenue sources available to local government for the two years 1976-77 and 1980-81. In 1976-77, local government rates were 48.6 per cent of total revenue received by local government as compared with 51.4 per cent from the Commonwealth and State governments and their own licensing arrangements.

By 1980-81, local government had to find 56.1 per cent of its revenue collections; the other revenue support fell to 43.9 per cent. In this period, the consumer price index rose approximately 43 per cent while all other indices affecting local government, such as the road cost index, rose by 56 per cent; average weekly earnings rose by 50 per cent; interest and redemption rose by 127 per cent; and local government rates and charges by 80 per cent-all well in excess of the CPI figure. The only index to increase at a rate less than the CPI was State government loans and subsidies, which rose by 26 per cent. That was a reflection as much on the high cost of interest that made borrowings uneconomical as it was on the decreased subsidy situation.

It is a statistical record of shrinking government assistance from the States, at a time when local government is faced with the imposition of additional State and Federal charges. Again, I instance indexed fuel excises and bank transactions tax imposed by the Commonwealth Government and registration and licence charges by State governments, while State and Federal governments are themselves exempt from local government rates and charges. One of the obvious Commonwealth biases in this analogy is the way in which fuel costs have increased because of excise indexation when compared with the amount local Governments are getting back for their road needs. No direct offset has been allowed by the Commonwealth in this analogy. That is a result of its increase in excise costs of 2c per litre in the August Budget and the automatic indexation of this excise and Australian bicentennial road development program levies every six months. In fact, where the greatest need for funds is in local government- that is, roads-the indexed amount of the ABRD levy will be directed towards Consolidated Revenue and not to the ABRD Trust Fund. It was never the intention of the Government that introduced the ABRD program-that is, the Fraser Government-that excise or levies would be indexed. Bearing in mind that the special 2c levy was earmarked wholly for the roads and highways and transport in Australia, it appears to me, to the Opposition and to the road users of Australia that if the levy is indexed the increase in the levy should also go to the some road program as the original 2c per litre.

It is to the Government's everlasting shame that when given the opportunity in this chamber by the shadow Minister for Transport, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher), last week or the week before, and in the Senate, further to amend the ABRD Bill the Government-all members and senators of the Australian Labor Party-went to water and declined to have the indexed funds also appropriated to the road funds trust. Effectively, this has meant that approximately $500m will be denied the road and transport needs of Australia from now until 1988-89.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The chart illustrates the insincerity of this Labor Government when it comes to doing something constructive and positive for local government. It did not agree to the amendment moved by the honourable member for Hume and I will be very interested in the attitude of this House towards my own amendment. There is insincerity in the actions of the Government and its back bench members.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Government has proved it is long on rhetoric but short on action so far as local government is concerned. I see this particular Bill, which is the subject of this debate, as being the appropriate vehicle to give local government the constitutional recognition it deserves and requires. The Act, in operation since 1976, will be subject to a partial review by the committee, the members and terms of reference yet to be announced. I have already said that I have concerns about the limitations in the terms of reference enabling the committee to come to grips with a complete review and update of the whole Act.

When presented in 1976, the Act introduced a positive aspect of the Fraser federalism policy to allow the Commonwealth to distribute funds direct to local government under the supervision of the State grants commissions with the power for local government to surcharge or credit the percentages set. Since 1976 the Advisory Council for Inter-Government Relations has been established and has published the results of its many inquiries into local government areas, dealing with such matters as constitutionality, finance, boundaries and many other aspects. The research staff of the Advisory Council are efficient, effective and impartial. In view of the standard of its reports, I believe it is the appropriate authority to conduct the inquiry of the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) into PIT sharing arrangements, an inquiry not limited by the present restrictions but encompassing the whole ambit of how proper constitutionality might be best effected through this Act that we are debating.

Unless the local government share of Federal revenues is properly determined and the funds therefore allocated unconditionally in each year, no amount of amendments to the State Acts and the Commonwealth Constitution to recognise local government in the form of more pious words will achieve the constitutional autonomy that local government needs and seeks. There are many problems existing between local government and the other spheres of government, that is State and Federal, where this Government has failed to act, as did so many other governments both Federal and State. There still exists too paternalistic an attitude by the other two spheres of government towards local government.

There is the problem of adequate financial arrangements that has led to the growth of local government debt structure and the increasing call on rates revenue for interest and redemption. There is no recognition for loss of rates when State or Federal authorities occupy local government land. At the same time local government is expected to pay its share of State and Commonwealth charges, that is, the bank transaction taxes and fuel excises, and local government feels this is discriminatory and should be redressed. There is also the question of the Income Tax Assessment Act's capacity to allow tax deductibility for State and Federal politicians' election expenses under the various sections of that Act, but the same expenses for election of councillors to local government are denied. Again, this appears to local government to discriminate between spheres of government.

There is the continuing fear that the Government, by fiddling with the consumer price index results, where the Medicare costs as a tax are omitted from the CPI, will not meet its commitment this year nor in the future to maintain the real value of the grant to local government. The real increase in costs as estimated by the Budget will be well above the discounted 7.5 per cent which the Budget predicts as the CPI for 1983-84 while PIT collections are estimated to increase by only 4.7 per cent. How will local government meet this gap when faced with a real increase in its costs exacerbated by government charges possibly close to 10 per cent when there is no guarantee of an increase in the grant beyond the 4. 7 per cent in PIT collections? At the same time local government is expected to alter its own priorities to pick up Commonwealth programs through tied grants and expected to contribute a portion of its own funds towards these programs, taking scarce funds away from its own programs, resources and services. I indicated earlier in my speech that I would move an amendment to put into context the basic things that have been mentioned in my speech at the second reading stage. I therefore move:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'Whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House notes the Government's failure to honour its pre-election promise in regard to the level of funding of general grants to local government'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Amendment Bill 1984 that we are discussing this morning is a Bill to amend the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act of 1976. The purpose of the legislation is to widen the tax base for tax sharing for local government. Indeed, this is a very progressive proposal put forward by the Hawke Labor Government to increase the allocation of funds from the national Government to local government.

SPEECH.PARA: It is expected that in the 1984-85 financial year this amending legislation we are dealing with today will increase the amount of money available to local government by $2m to $3m-a small but significant amount when one considers the effect that Commonwealth funds have in assisting local government to provide the services that it does. This Government plans to make local government a real partner in the Commonwealth-State-local government system. We intend to do something substantial to assist local government, unlike the Opposition, which offers platitudes without much real substance. The Opposition spokesman seems to be very interested in who will be on committee and matters such as that. This Government is interested in putting cash into the hands of local government so it can provide services.

The present Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act was introduced in 1977 and in the last financial year $454m was distributed by the Commonwealth Grants Commission to 839 local government authorities in Australia. A quite substantial amount of Commonwealth funds went to the five local government authorities in my electorate of Grayndler to allow them to provide services for the people living in my electorate. The Marrickville Municipal Council received $1.93m, the Canterbury Municipal Council received $2.46m, the Ashfield Municipal Council received $831,000, the Burwood Municipal Council received $518,000 and the Strathfield Municipal Council received $402,000. In the case of the Marrickville Municipal Council, for instance, that figure is equivalent to 10 per cent of its income-a substantial amount of money, being provided by the national Government to assist local government.

This money is provided in recognition of the diversification of functions that local government has undertaken in recent years. Indeed, it is betterment money. It helps those who have shown that they are willing to help their constituents and it provides a capacity for them to afford to plan for the future, to provide better libraries, Meals on Wheels services, open space, social workers et cetera . It has helped to bring local government out of the roads and footpaths era. When members of the present Opposition were in government, they were concerned to try to reduce the amount of money that local government authorities received for road making. The Hawke Government intends to make local government a full partner in the system and to raise the status of the third tier in the Federal- State-local government sphere.

In the Budget appropriations for this year local government received excellent support from the Government. There is money for roads schemes, with Commonwealth payments expected to be $994m in 1983-84-an increase of the order of $300m on the previous Government's proposals. General revenue assistance to local government was increased by $35m to $461m. Some $1.5m has been provided for the regional community development program a quarter of a million dollars has been provided for the Local Government Information Service. Assistance for local government scholarship schemes has been increased by 45 per cent to $35,000 in 1983-84, the annual borrowing limit for smaller authorities not requiring an Australian Loan Council program has been increased to $1.8m, and $250m has been allocated under the community employment program, which local government will share in. Total roads assistance, for construction and maintenance, will increase under this Government by $382m to $1,233m-a massive increase of 45 per cent. Funds for children's services have been increased by 70 per cent to $26m and assistance has been increased by the Hawke Government under the aerodrome local ownership plan by $15m-a 51 per cent increase. Under this program $44.7m will go to local government this year.

The Opposition continues on its disinformation program. We have heard the carping of the Opposition spokesman today in his allegation that the excise revenues earmarked for local government road programs are being syphoned off to consolidated revenue as a result of a decision taken at the last Budget to index the price of fuel. Needless to say, members of the Opposition had a very poor record when they were in government. What did they do for roads and local government in the seven years that they were running this country?

The former Government quadrupled the price of petrol including diesel over that seven-year period. Therefore I point out to the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) is the National Party spokesman on local government and transport- the National Party claims to represent the man on the land-that his Government even increased the price of dieseline. So much for separating the rhetoric from the fact. Indeed, under the previous Government there was a 23 per cent reduction in real terms in funding for roads. We heard this carping from the Opposition spokesman today about how the present Government is supposed to have deprived local government of $2.7m under the excise proposals. Under the former Government there was a reduction of 23 per cent in real terms in road funding for local government. The Opposition has the hide in this House today to carp about $2.7m.

What are the facts? The facts are that an extra $70m is being made available by the Government this year to all councils in Australia under the jobs on local roads program in fulfilment of this Government's election promise. The Opposition complains that $2.7m has gone to Consolidated Revenue, but it does not mention that this Government has provided more money for road programs than any government in Australia's history. The extra $70m does not even get a ; mention by the Opposition. All it wants to do is carp about the $2.7m. What is the fact? The proposal that was adopted in 1982 by the then Federal Government, the Fraser Government, and supported by the States and local government, provided for an amount equivalent to 1c per litre on fuel excises to be paid from the Consolidated Revenue Fund to the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund for expenditure on road works under the bicentenary road development program.

The Trust Fund legislation which was introduced by the previous Government currently makes no provision to increase payments for the fund beyond the flat lc and later 2c equivalent originally decided on. The Opposition spokesman knows that. He knows that the Bicentennial Road Fund is not an open-ended fund. The Fund has a target of $2,500m. He knows, as do the other members of the Opposition, that the $2.7m that has been raised from excise was never meant to go to the Bicentennial Road Trust Fund. He knows that and it is terrible that in this House he should present other than the truth. It is terrible that the Opposition and the National Party spokesman on roads and local government have been running around Australia scaring local government authorities into believing that this Government was not doing anything for the provision of local roads. The fact is that this Government has provided $1,268m for roads, a 49 per cent increase. It is not a decrease; it is a 49 per cent increase on what the previous Government provided.

The expenditure on national arterial and local roads under the previous Liberal -National Party Government in 1982-83 was a paltry $851m. The Roads Grants Act money that has been provided by this Government is $778m. In fact, we have provided nearly the same amount under the Roads Grants Act as the former Government provided for the whole road program for Australia. We have provided $ 420m under the bicentenary roads program. We have provided $70m for the jobs on local roads program, an initiative of the Hawke Labor Government to provide work for people in country areas and to provide roads for those people. That has been a 49 per cent increase in the amount provided for roads in this country.

In my State of New South Wales the previous Government allocated $263.4m, a paltry amount when we consider the size of the road network in New South Wales. Under the present Government there has been a 25 per cent increase in the funds available to local government authorities for roads in New South Wales. There has been allocated $243.5m under the Roads Grants Act, $135.2m under the bicentenary roads program, and $23.4m under the jobs on local roads program, a total of $402.1m, a 52 per cent increase.

What do members of the Opposition say to the country when they are asked where they really stand? At present members of the Opposition in the Senate are trying , by way of technicalities, to stop the payment of money to local government and State authorities to fund road programs. The Government's attitude shows once again its lack of practical understanding of what is involved these days with local government in rural areas, in fast- growing areas, in areas outside the metropolitan area, where there is a great need for additional and new services, not only in respect of roads and bridges but also in respect of opening up new areas, where large expenditure is required to make available new residential subdivisions. Quite apart from what is contributed by developers, councils have to provide a wide range of services, such as water, sewerage and paving. This is costly. TALK.START.PARA: —About $70m.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Amendment Bill 1984 which is now before the House is to make arrangements consequential upon the introduction of the prescribed payments system of taxation. SPEECH.PARA: Regrettably that legislation, enacted by the Fraser Government, is one of the few constructive contributions made since Federation to local government by the conservative parties in this House. When that legislation was originally implemented it was intended to operate, in my view, as a conservative trick to cover up what were in fact reduced specific purpose grants to the States. Clearly the record of the conservative parties has historically been one of outright opposition to an expanded and increased voice for local government.

In the course of this debate we have heard a great deal from the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) and the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Ian Robinson) about the Australian Labor Party purportedly being long on rhetoric and short on action when it comes to local government. Let me just examine the record of Labor in the national Parliament in regard to local government. Before the election of the Whitlam Labor Government relations between the Commonwealth Government and local government were virtually non-existent. When the Whitlam Government began to promote a better deal for local government and national action by this Parliament to secure a better deal for local government, the Government was blocked at every turn in this chamber by the Liberal-National Party Opposition. It opposed virtually every attempt to advance the cause of local government.

It was the conservatives who opposed the Whitlam Government's proposal that local government be represented at the Australian Constitutional Convention. It was the conservatives who opposed the Whitlam Government's proposal that local government be represented on the Australian Loan Council and again, when the Whitlam Government put a referendum to the people proposing that local government receive funds direct from the Federal Government, it was the conservatives who went out into the community and campaigned against that constitutional change. Such is the record of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia when it comes to local government.

The Hawke Labor Government has already established a proud record in the field of support for local government. As the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) indicated in his contribution to this debate, the Hawke Labor Government , for the first time, has appointed a Minister who is responsible for local government and a ministry which is getting on with the job of promoting local government reform and innovation throughout the country. It was the Hawke Labor Government that enabled local government to be represented at the National Economic Summit Conference and, following that, to be represented on the Economic Planning Advisory Council.

I turn again to the record of the Fraser Government. Perhaps the most reprehensible action of the Fraser Government was to slash the direct and indirect tied grants to local government from the Whitlam Government level of $ 173m in 1975-76 to only $45m in the first full year of conservative government. All this was done in pursuance of the phoney federalism policy of the Liberal and National parties. Having had some experience of what conservatives are like at the local government level, what a feeling of deja vu I have when I come into this Parliament and find that the conservatives in this Parliament say that this national Parliament cannot do certain things because they are a State responsibility or because they are a local government responsibility. Of course, conservatives at the local level are saying that local government cannot undertake initiatives to advance community well-being because such initiatives are a State responsibility or a Federal responsibility. Time and again this hoary old argument is trotted out. This phoney States rights argument, this phoney division of responsibilities argument, is used by the conservatives to thwart social progress in this country. Time and again this argument is trotted out in this Parliament, as it is at the local level.

I turn particularly to the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1976. In a spirit of bipartisan debate I give support to that legislation as a positive initiative taken by conservatives in support of local government. It is legislation which the Hawke Labor Government is pleased to continue. The effect of that legislation was, after a phasing-in period, to provide 2 per cent of personal income tax receipts as untied revenue assistance for local government. But I stress that it took six years of phasing in by the conservatives to confer that 2 per cent on local government. I agree with what was said by the honourable member for Cowper when he implied that the amendment before the House today is substantially a technical amendment to maintain the 2 per cent contribution. That is not what I see as the major issue.

The members of this Parliament are aware that the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) has initiated a comprehensive review of the operations of the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act. No doubt this review will consider the need to ensure an alternative formula for funding local government should the area of personal income tax not be a substantial growth area in future years. This review, as I have previously indicated, is a welcome national initiative in the field of local government reform but falls far short of the needed total review of local government functions and powers.

The Commonwealth Parliament is to be complimented on what I hope is bipartisan support for the concept of a guaranteed level of untied grands to local government. I stress that the commitment to the continuing grant to local government of 2 per cent of personal income tax is a bipartisan commitment. This commitment by the Parliament leads the world and is at odds with developments in this field in other federal jurisdictions in other parts of the world. In most federal systems, local government has a weak relationship with the federal or central government and, indeed, in countries with a unitary system of government the clear tendency is for local government to be funded through a system of tied subsidies and grants.

While the Hawke Labor Government recognises the importance of tied grants and a potential for decentralised administration of Australian Government programs, we also recognise the importance of local democracy and of local government being substantially in control of its own destiny. Local authorities are ultimately accountable at the ballot box and they need guaranteed financial independence to be able to impelement programs of their own choosing. To that extent too, I think there is bipartisan support throughout much of this Parliament for the view that as much as possible local government ought to be the master of its own destiny and ought not to be artificially constrained in its own revenue raising efforts and exercise of powers by other levels of government.

I must say, addressing my remarks to some of the earlier comments made in the course of the debate, that it is important that local government financing not be discussed just for the sake of political point scoring. I am rather disappointed that the amendment moved by the honourable member for Dawson is not one of substance which seeks to advance the position of local government and its dealings with the national Parliament. Rather it is simply a fairly generalised and unspecific attempt at political point scoring.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. Under standing order 293 the Opposition is not allowed to amend a money Bill.
—The point of order is upheld.

—If the honourable member for Dawson is not able to amend a money Bill I wonder what on earth the Opposition proposes to do as an alternative to advance the cause of local government. We have not seen anything specific or any constructive proposals from the Opposition that would advance in any specific way the cause of local government. What we have seen, as I have already indicated, are generalised attempts at political point scoring in an attempt further to divide the community rather like the debate that took place in this chamber yesterday in relation to the question of immigration.

SPEECH.PARA: I stress that it is important to understand that questions of local government financing must not be dismissed as a remote academic debate. I believe that without continued guaranteed levels of local government funding and income, the very existence of local government democracy is at risk and this in turn, I believe, threatens the existence of national democracy itself. In the United Kingdom, for example, the Thatcher Conservative Government, elected in 1979, quickly introduced regulations in the United Kingdom Local Government Planning and Land Act to allow the Secretary of State to fix a level of expenditure for each individual local authority and expenditure beyond this level could lead to a reduction in grant. This means, of course, that it is more difficult for a local authority in the United Kingdom to adopt policies at variance with those of the British Government and this trend has worsened in that country in recent years. I give that example because I believe that Australia ought to resist those authoritarian trends which have so increasingly been evident in the Australian States. The bipartisan commitment of the Commonwealth in ensuring a guaranteed 2 per cent of personal income tax to local government is an important preliminary step in ensuring local autonomy. The Bill furthers that commitment and I commend it to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join this important debate on the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Amendment Bill 1984. This is a very important arrangement because councils can use this funding to offset rises in rates, the cost of roads or the general cost of services within the community.

SPEECH.PARA: From my past experience I know that for many years councils have been very concerned about the tied grants that they are receiving from the States. They are very concerned about the impingement generally of State and Commonwealth powers upon local government. We have to understand the fact that councils are close to the people. We have to understand the general problems faced by local government in providing services that people need. If Australia is going to progress in the way we want it to, bearing in mind that we have such a large continent, it is essential that our three tiers of government are properly defined and that no particular government tries to supersede the constitutional rights of others.

I want to point out that any attempt, such as we saw from 1972 to 1975 when the Whitlam Administration endeavoured to put money directly into the hands of regional councils, is doomed to complete failure. While the foundations of our system are good and while the three systems of government operate in the way that we believe they rightfully should, we have no fears about getting value for the dollar and about the development of our nation. Therefore, I make a plea that it is important that the autonomy of what we term our third tier of government is preserved and that councils should be interfered with less by State governments in particular. I blame all the States of Australia for this interference. We have seen the problems that arise with respect to tied grants. The honourable member for Cowper (Mr Ian Robinson) spoke this morning and the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) spoke last night about community employment program grants. These grants, which are creating work for 70,000 people throughout Australia, may be good in their place. The Commonwealth Government will receive approximately $146m in taxes from the people who will be employed under this program. Yet local government in this country is expected to contribute one-third of the cost of this program. Local governments are not actually compelled to join the scheme. I do not think that any more than two councils out of seven in my electorate of Lyne can become involved simply because they are not able to make an allocation in their estimates for this purpose. So this tax sharing scheme, as far as the CEP is concerned, virtually excludes the councils. We should look at councils' responsibilities. The Commonwealth gets the taxation directly from any mining operation or any other type of operation being carried out in a shire or municiplaity. Therefore it is so important that we should see that at least a fair proportion of these moneys goes back to the councils, particularly those councils which have obligations to carry out works which are beyond the normal meaning of things that they do.

New South Wales received approximately $167m under this tax sharing arrangement . That figure is for the 1983-84 financial year. Within my electorate of Lyne, the Greater Taree City Council received approximately $1.34m. However, the lowest allocation is approximately $350,000. It is terribly important that, where we can, we extend this tax sharing arrangement. I, like the honourable member for Dawson, am extremely disappointed, particularly in view of the promises made by the Government before it came to power. It said that, in real money terms, it would maintain the value of the money under the tax sharing arrangement. We know that there was an 11.2 per cent increase in the consumer price index for last year. Yet, the increase under the tax sharing arrangement was 8.2 per cent. Is it any wonder that the honourable member for Dawson moved an amendment today to the legislation stressing concern about our feelings with respect to this matter?

All States of Australia, particularly New South Wales, are putting greater responsibility on to the councils within their States. I mentioned a while ago when the honourable member for Cowper was speaking that New South Wales received $176m under the tax sharing agreements. However, it has been estimated by the Local Government and Shires Associations in that State that $70m was taken out of that total amount by the New South Wales Government. I will inform honourable members of the purposes for which it was taken out. In 1982 the New South Wales Government dropped to 50 per cent the subsidy on pensioner rebate which cost the councils of New South Wales an extra $30m for the year. The local government assistance fund was abolished which cost an extra $9.5m. The contribution to the Board of Fire Commissioners of New South Wales was also dropped. Those three issues assist to make up the $70m that I mentioned a while ago. Not only have those funds been taken away from the councils, but also those councils are expected to pick up the tab if they are to represent their people in a proper way with respect to health care within the community, social security generally, child care, aged care and sporting facilities. These are all matters that all councils today, particularly those in growing areas, find that they have responsibilities for. These responsibilities are virtually responsibilities of the Commonwealth and the States. However, councils have to accept those responsibilities if they are to represent their people properly and to provide services within the community.

Council costs are going up just as costs are going up for industry and business within the community. Changes in industrial relations conditions have meant that working hours, particularly for workers employed by county councils, have been reduced to 35 hours a week and to 38 hours a week for workers employed by local government generally. In view of this I believe that today the ratepayer is not receiving value for the money that he and she are paying to councils. In balancing the situation a little, I believe that some of the councils have now reached the stage, as I mentioned earlier in relation to health care, social security and sporting fields, that they are being forced to neglect the vital responsibilities which they have towards the maintenance of their services such as sewerage, water supplies, roads, kerbing and guttering, footpaths and other matters within their areas. That will occur unless we, the Commonwealth Government, continue to build upon the funds that are available from the Commonwealth for the councils.

Today we have a great responsiblity to primary producers to see that our roads are in a reasonable condition and to see that services are available within a community that will allow the industries to operate, to expand and to see that they get the goods to market so that we can compete with other countries. It should be untied and the councils which are in the best position to gauge the areas in which the moneys should be expended should be able to expend the money themselves.

Only a month ago, as the honourable member for Dawson said, we had a Bill before the House relating to the bicentennial road funding scheme. That was another initiative by the Fraser Government. We know that, today, the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) can turn around and say that the Government is spending an extra 40 per cent more on roads than the previous administration did . Of course he can because we initiated the bicentennial road funding program for Australia that has been so well received by all the councils throughout Australia. It was disappointing to the Opposition to realise that the amount derived from the six-monthly indexation was not added to the 2c which is available under the Australian bicentennial road development program. TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House has a general debate covering this Bill and the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Income Equalization Deposits) Bill 1984 as they are related matters. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Loan (Income Equalization Deposits) Amendment Bill 1984 and the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Income Equalization Deposits) Bill 1984 are of very great importance to Australia's primary producers. The income equalisation deposits scheme, which was introduced by the former Government, proved to be of remarkable assistance to many Australian primary producers in allowing them the very needed facility of averaging or equalising their incomes over a period. Our concern is that the changes that have been made by the Government and which are proposed to be implemented by this legislation have the effect of virtually destroying the income equalisation deposits scheme as a useful aid to Australia's primary producers.

SPEECH.PARA: In summary, we believe that the Government has made a mess of the income equalisation deposits scheme. We believe that had the Government really intended to destroy it as a vehicle for providing assistance to Australia's primary producers it could not have done a better job than it has with the proposals it wishes to put into law with this legislation. If ever one could find in the policies of the present Government an example of its continuing bias against rural people in Australia it is the provisions in the Bill before us. I know that in reply my colleague the Acting Treasurer (Mr Hurford) will undoubtedly argue that these changes were needed to prevent the possibility of some abuses in the interaction between the averaging provisions of the existing taxation legislation as far as they affect farmers and the operation of the income equalisation deposits scheme.

Let me say that to the extent that there was any scope for abuse in that area we would totally support measures taken by the Government to prevent that occurring. We believe that objective has been achieved by the changes that have been made in relation to the averaging provisions. There is absolutely no need to go the step further, as the Government has done, in making the changes that have been made to the income equalisation deposit scheme, because what the Government has done is convert a very valuable income equalisation deposit scheme into nothing more than an alternative form of holding government paper. The deposits now are nothing more than glorified savings bank deposits. They do not provide any incentive. The uselessness of the new IED scheme is illustrated by the fact that now only $3m is deposited in it compared with a sum of about $ 160m which was the situation when the changes were announced in May.

The Opposition proposes that the present proposals of the Government be changed in three respects. The first would restore the income equalisation deposit facility as a vehicle for helping farmers to equalise their incomes in circumstances where that is justified but, at the same time, would prevent such arrangements from being in any way abused. I make it perfectly clear that we do not believe the IED scheme and its interaction with the averaging provisions of the tax legislation should be allowed to produce any abuses. Our first proposal would be that, unlike the Government's proposal, any deposit into IEDs be deductible in full from the income of the person in question in the year in which the deposit is made. That is not provided for under the Government's proposals. In those circumstances one of the great appeals of this scheme is taken away from the existing arrangements. So first of all we would propose that the deposits be deductible in full.

Our second proposal would be that interest be payable only on the investment componment. If a person paying a marginal tax rate of, say, 46c in the dollar deposits $96,000 the interest would be payable on only $50,000 of that $96,000 component. In other words, interest is payable only on the investment component. We concede that if one is to get the benefit of full deduction in the year of income in which the deposit is made it is a bit rich on top of that to go the step further and obtain the interest rate at a reasonable rate of interest-I stress the words 'reasonable rate of interest'-on the total amount of the deposit. That is the second change that we propose.

The third change that we propose would be to continue paying interest at the rate that was applicable at the time of the Government's announcement in May last year. That component of the amendment does not go as far as some people have urged upon the Opposition and undoubtedly upon the Government. This is an area in which, undoubtedly, the Government has received quite a number of representations from farmer and rural organisations. Some of those recommendations, in fact a great number of them, were found by the Opposition to be compelling, sensible and responsible, particularly the arguments that were advanced by the National Farmers Federation, but equally we think that the suggestion that the interest rate be 2 to 3 per cent above the long term bond rate is perhaps going a little further than is required. We have fixed the rate of interest as that which was payable at the time of the Government's announcement last May. That may well be open to some objection and some amendment. It may well be that a case can be made for a slightly higher rate of interest or a slightly lower rate-we are not totally dogmatic about that-but for the purposes of demonstrating our position on this we suggest that the interest rate should be about what it was in May last year.

What does the Opposition believe should be done? For starters there should not be a scheme that allows for abuse. We accept that and we will support any changes that achieve that goal. Secondly, we believe the income equalisation deposit instrument has lost its attraction to primary producers. A fall from $ 160m to $3m in just on a year is a pretty graphic illustration of how unpopular these deposits have become with primary producers. Undoubtedly, the Government will, and can, advance some explanations that this is related to the fluctuating fortunes of primary producers. I would be prepared to accept that some of the change has been due to that, but the Government cannot explain away a drop of $ 157m in the space of only one year. I believe that needs to be kept in mind. We have kept that in mind in the proposals which we have made.
We will not divide on the second reading of the legislation, but we will be moving an amendment to the motion that the Bill be read a second time. The motion will be in the following terms:
That all words after ''That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
''the Bill be withdrawn and redrafted to provide for-
(1) deposits to be deductible in full;

(2) interest to be payable on the investment component only of deposits where the investment component is equal to the balance of the deposit as if tax had been payable in the year of deposit at the rate applicable to a producer's average income, and
(3) interest to be payable at the rate of 9.5 per cent per annum''.

We in the Opposition believe that if the income equalisation deposit scheme were changed along those lines it would regain its attractiveness to primary producers but, at the same time, it would not provide avenues for unfair exploitation and avenues that confer unfair advantages on primary producers.

I know that in debates of this kind it is the habit of some honourable members to take the opportunity of having a go at our farmers and primary producers. I know that it is a fashionable sport among some members of the Australian Labor Party-I stress the words 'some members'; not all of them are so insensitive-to have a go at Australia's farmers. Somehow or other they think it is clever to have a go at them. If ever there were a time that it was not fashionable, clever or smart to have a go at Australia's farmers it is now. If it had not been for the rural recovery we would not have the spectacle of the Australian Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in this House day after day saying how much the economy had improved.

The reality is that the improvement that has taken place in the Australian economy over the last year is due almost entirely to the revival of the farm sector which reminds us, once again, of the colossal dependence of the Australian economy on the health of the farm sector. When we think that perhaps there were some pieces of legislation which for a short period conferred special treatment on farmers, it does all of us well to remember what the drought of more than a year ago did to the Australian community and the dramatic effect that it had on not only the livelihood of those people in the farm sector and those who depend on the farm sector but also the total Australian economy. I do not think that the damage that was done by that drought will ever be fully calculated. The best illustration of that is the way in which, in the space of six or nine months, there has been this colossal turn-around. If one looks at the growth figure of 10 per cent about which the Prime Minister is so fond of talking one sees what is left of that 10 per cent when the farm sector is taken out of it. Not a great deal of that 10 per cent is left when the farm sector is taken out of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Give us the figures.
—It does all of us a great deal of good, including the honourable member for McMillan, to consider that. The honourable member represents quite a number of farmers. He knows what I am talking about.
—More than you do.
—Yes, he does.
—So do I.

—The Minister represents more people who occupy the farms which they own than I do. I am very pleased that he is in the House because it really does all of us well to remember that enormous contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it can be fairly said that such improvement that has occurred in the Australian economy over the last year would not have occurred had it not been for the colossal contribution made by the revival of the farm sector as a result of the breaking of the drought. I think it is relevant not only to the sectoral balance between the different parts of the Australian community but also to the political debate that takes place from time to time in Australia as to who is responsible for certain things occurring. A debate on income equalisation deposits provides an opportunity of reminding the House not only of the central importance of the farm sector and its enormous contribution to our export earnings and to the overall wealth of the country, as we were reminded by that very excellent maiden speech by the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) this week, but also, in the context of the current political debate, that if we leave aside the breaking of the drought the Prime Minister would not have a great deal to crow about. That is really what it all boils down to. It is something which, if I may borrow a few phrases from the Prime Minister, we will be reminding him about a fair bit over the next few months, because it lies at the very heart of political debate.

Income equalisation deposits for several years until last May were a very valuable and legitimate method of assistance to the primary producers of Australia. We believe that the changes made to the IED scheme virtually destroy it as a useful aid to Australia's primary producers. I would like to believe that that is not the Government's intention, but, I fear, whether it is the intention or not, that is certainly the result. We are putting forward a proposal which in no way opens the gate for abuse. I want immediately to meet that possible argument from some members of the Australian Labor Party that anything we propose in the primary producer area represents the opening of some abuse. It is certainly not designed to do that. We are proposing something that will restore the attractiveness of IEDs. It will turn around the flight from IEDs and convert what the Government wants an IED to be-another form of Government paper, a glorified savings bank deposit-into an attractive instrument . We are proposing an amendment with three components. It will achieve that objective. It deserves the support of the House.

I hope that the Government in the course of this debate will give consideration to the proposals that have been put forward. It really ought to understand that when the National Farmers Federation complains about the effect of the Government's proposals it is not just beating a sectional drum. It is also drawing attention to what has occurred as a result of the Government's changes to the IED scheme. I think the Government ought to take account of that. If it really wishes to offer a scheme that provides legitimate help to Australian primary producers to even out incomes without abuses, it will accept the amendments that have been put forward for these and other reasons that will be developed by my colleagues in the course of this debate.

I urge the Government quite seriously to consider the amendment put forward by the Opposition. It is a reasonable one. We are not proposing any rorts. We are proposing a change that would make IEDs attractive once again. Surely, given the continuing dependence of this country on wealth generation from the primary producer sector that is a legitimate goal and one that a government interested in primary producers would want to embrace. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to keep my comments on the Loan (Income Equalization Deposits) Amendment Bill and the Income Tax Assessment Amendment ( Income Equalization Deposits) Bill reasonably short. But I think it is pertinent to respond to some of the issues that have been raised by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). He referred particularly to the contribution of the rural sector to our overall economic performance and growth. I could not agree more with the honourable member for Bennelong that the contribution of our rural sector to the overall economy in Australia is indeed a very significant one. It is a magnificent contribution and a particuarly important one in terms of our export growth, which has such a high multiplier effect through our local economy .

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Bennelong suggested that virtually the sole reason for our economic recovery and our projected 10 per cent growth in real gross domestic product throughout 1984 could be attributed to the breaking of the drought. Whilst I certainly agree that the breaking of the drought provided a significant stimulus throughout the economy because of the support that it gave to the farm sector after such a significant time, I certainly could not agree that it has been responsible for the 10 per cent predicted growth in the GDP during 1984. I am sure that the honourable member for Bennelong would not really suggest that the total improvement in the economy has been due to the breaking of the drought.

I have in front of me some recent figures on the economy. They show that, for instance, in the December quarter of 1983 there was a growth in GDP of 1.9 per cent. I just mention that because there was a real growth despite a fall in the farm sector. I think that is an important statistic. I have said that real GDP growth throughout 1983-84 could reach 10 per cent. I think that the rural sector 's contribution to that would be about one-quarter.

I think it is also important to say to the honourable member for Bennelong that there have been real improvements in the economy in other areas. Retail sales in the three months to the end of February 1984 were 2.1 per cent up in real terms on the previous three months and 8.2 per cent higher than in the three months to the end of February 1983. Production figures for the March quarter of 1984 show a rise in all of the 31 Australian Bureau of Statistics figures, with the exception of beer, over the March quarter of 1983. The best results, of course, have been in consumer durables, motor vehicles, house building materials and the steel industry. So there is some sustained recovery throughout the economy. Of course, the farm sector's contribution to that is crucial but it is not the sole responsible factor.

I wish to make some comments about the old income equalisation deposits scheme and then to address the question raised by the honourable member for Bennelong about the participation of farmers in the amended scheme proposed in this legislation. Income equalisation deposits were introduced in 1976 by the previous Government to assist eligible primary producers to minimise the fluctuations that occur in their taxable incomes due to seasonal factors and changes in commodity prices. The scheme was a form of forward tax averaging and was designed to enable primary producers to even out the effects of fluctuating income on their tax liabilities over a period of years. In effect, income was transferred from the good years in which the primary producer's marginal tax rate was high to the poor years in which the marginal tax rate was lower.

In 1977 the former Government introduced what was known as the 'in-out' provisions of the tax averaging system under which primary producers paid tax at the average rate only when taxable income exceeded average income. They did that for obvious reasons. When taxable income was less than average income, tax was paid at ordinary rates. I do not think there is any question that the introduction of that provision changed demonstrably and significantly the relationship between IEDs and tax averaging. I am sure that the honourable member for Bennelong acknowledges that it led to significant criticism throughout the community, particularly on the grounds of equity of the IED scheme. I note that the honourable member in his amendment, has made it quite clear that the proposals he has put would, in his view, ensure that there was no possibility for abuse of this scheme. I think he was implying by those comments that there had been some abuse or misuse of the old IED scheme, particularly as it related to the automatic in-out provisions of tax averaging.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you supporting the amendment?

—No, I am certainly not supporting the amendment. I have just made it clear that the existing arrangements for the IEDs and tax averaging have led to abuse in the past and it has been necessary for this Government to make changes in that area. As I have said, there has been a great deal of public criticism, particularly on the combination of those two factors. I want to make some more points about the old IED scheme. Both in my view and in the Government's view those old arrangements did have a significant degree of inequity in that the producers at the highest marginal rate of tax-that is, those with the highest incomes-benefited most, proportionately. The small 4 per cent to 5 per cent of farmers whose marginal tax rates approached 60c in the dollar received proportionately greater taxation benefits than did the majority of full time farmers, whose marginal tax rate is 20 per cent or less. It is interesting that if one looks at statistics which break up farm incomes according to marginal tax rates one finds that more than 50 per cent of farmers have a marginal tax rate of 20 per cent to 22 per cent or lower. The benefits they received from the IED scheme were considerably less than those received by the very small percentage of farmers whose marginal tax rates were much higher.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition to those inherent tax inequities of the previous scheme, it has been suggested that the scheme was not being used in a manner which was consistent with the original objective of that scheme, which was to be a buffer against hard years and against years of low income. I think it was being misused to some degree. The honourable member for Bennelong mentioned the contributions under the previous scheme as being $160m. Only a small proportion, somewhere between 4 per cent and 7 per cent, of farmers were using the scheme. Allegations were made, not just from us when we were in Opposition, that that scheme was being used purely for the purpose of taxation strategy and tax avoidance or tax minimisation. They were the accusations that were made and, of course, it was necessary for the Government to look at them and to respond to those criticisms.

I want to make some brief comments on the suggestions that the Opposition has made that the changes that the Government has made to the IED scheme have effectively emasculated or destroyed the scheme to such an extent that it has just become another form of saving. He raised the whole question of farmers' participation in the new IED arrangements. I want to make a few points. I refer firstly to the relative attractiveness of the IED scheme. The return on income equalisation deposits is one factor and one factor alone which influences the level of participation in the scheme. The range of investments available for farmers includes a number of financial investments and on and off farm equity investments. I do not think there is any doubt that following the breaking of the drought in 1983-that very disastrous drought for so many farmers-farmers are likely to have invested very heavily in on-farm investments to overcome a backlog of deferred expenditure. The honourable member for Bennelong suggested that that may be a reason why the present contributions to IEDs are somewhat lower than what they were 12 months ago. I think he could have gone a bit further and suggested that that was a very powerful reason why the level of contribution may have dropped. I have some figures here that would tend to confirm that farmers have put money back into on-farm investments. For example, tractor sales have increased by 20 per cent in the five months to February 1984 over the corresponding period of 1982-83. In other words, farmers have put money into on-farm investment. They have also put money into trucks, utilities, fencing and other capital improvements on farm.

Opportunities for off-farm financial investments include the repayment of debt and the investment in building society accounts, cash and other types of management trusts and government securities. They are all available as well as IEDs. We do not have data on the take-up by farmers of government securities such as Aussie Bonds or investment in building society accounts. It is unavailable. But if we look at the rate of interest paid by the IEDs it does seem that they are more than competitive or, at the very worst, comparable with alternative forms of investment for farmers. So there is still a financial incentive in terms of off-farm financial investment for farmers to put their money into IEDs.

There has always been a marked degree of seasonality in terms of contributions in the previous IED scheme, and the obvious reasons for that are the tax requirements. Under the new arrangements those tax benefits will not exist so we will not get the degree of seasonality that we would have expected under the previous scheme. To compare-as the honourable member for Bennelong attempted to- contributions that are supposedly in IEDs at the moment against something of 12 months or more ago is a rather tenuous argument. It cannot really be done.

The extent to which the new IEDs will be used as an investment medium will depend on their attractiveness compared with private sector financial investments. The main determinant will be factors such as the level of interest rates and the relative liquidity of deposits. The interest paid is 2 per cent above the most recent two-year government bond tender. TALK.START.PARA: —I want Opposition members to tell me how they would increase the number of Europeans. If they wish to do it through family migration, they will have to reduce the standard and take more elderly unskilled people who may not get jobs in Australia. They may try to tell us that they would do it by lifting the number of skilled applicants under the skilled labour category. If they do that there is no guarantee, unless they impose quotas especially for people from Europe and the United Kingdom, that they will get any more of those people than they will Asians. To think otherwise is highly uncomplimentary of the skill level in the Asian nations today. For instance, if we said we would take more computer experts, would it not be reasonable to expect that we would get many people from Japan and Singapore? I leave Opposition members with that thought.

—I address my question to the Minister for Science and Technology. Is it a fact that this country faces dramatic structural problems and that the impact of rapid technological change is placing enormous pressure on our labour force, affecting expectations for future employment and time use? Does the Government accept that the time has come to focus public attention on the implications for labour force planning, education, recreation, leisure and tourism? Following the successful National Technology Conference, will the Minister convene a national conference with his ministerial colleagues so that these important issues can be discussed and addressed?

—The suggestion of the honourable member for Hawker is a very valuable one. We need to stimulate public interest in and understanding of the value of time use outside work. Work is central to nearly everybody-economically and psychologically-and is one of life's major purposes. The withdrawal of work can have absolutely crippling psychological effects. For people with a traditional working class experience, work accounts for up to 14 per cent of a lifetime. In the case of a person who lives for 75 years and works a standard working year from the age of 15 years to 65 years-a 50 year stretch-the figure is 13.8 per cent of the lifetime. We spend one-seventh of all our lives at work. We have not given enough emphasis to the value of time use both in and out of work. We need to recognise the possibility-it is by no means a certainty-that the proportion of time devoted to work may well fall below 14 per cent and we should face up to useful ways to employ the other 86 per cent. Human society has always been fascinated by the question of life after death, and we ought to pay some attention to life before death too. I have discussed the matter with my colleagues the Ministers for Employment and Industrial Relations, Education and Youth Affairs, and Sport, Recreation and Tourism. That sounds like more than three Ministers, but it is only three. We agree in principle that such a conference on employment, education, leisure and technology should take place and the details of the time, place, specific agenda and invitation list will be worked out between us. I will advise the House when we have further details. Following his dazzling success in opening the National Technology Conference, I have no doubt who will be invited to open the batting.

—I address my question to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I preface it by saying that at no time in yesterday's debate did I call for a balancing of the migration program by increasing the number of Europeans. I called for a return to bipartisanship.
—Why don't you make a personal explanation?

—Yes, I will make one if I am misrepresented again. Is it not a fact that under the skilled and business migration program, the people eligible under the selection criteria at the moment happen to be, largely, Caucasian? Is it not a fact that the trade union movement has stipulated qualifications for skills which are met by people more probably coming from the United Kingdom as at this moment? Is it not a fact also that the trade union movement asked the Minister to cut back on skilled migration, and is it not a fact that as a consequence of that some 40,000 fewer people came into Australia, and those 40,000 happen to be Caucasian?

—I do not have on me the figures for the breakdown on national or race grounds of the Government's former skilled and business migration program. I do know that what the honourable member for Balaclava says is correct: The Australian Council of Trade Unions asked this Government to reduce the intake of skilled workers. I expect that it would have put the same request to the Opposition when it was in government. The union movement debates the wisdom of a policy of importing large numbers of so-called skilled workers during a time of economic downturn. The honourable member will remember that he brought in about 40,000 people in those skilled and business categories in 1982-83, which made up by far the largest component of the migration program. We turned that down to about 11,000 because we could see that it was a basically backward-looking policy. It was based upon a list of occupations allegedly in demand provided by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. We reduced substantially that intake of skilled labour. As the honourable member well knows, we are looking at a new system which will be forward-looking and based upon predictions of expected demand in a number of key areas of occupation. I do expect that there will be some upturn in those areas. I do not expect that simply bringing in a few more thousand skilled migrants in categories which have yet to be determined will automatically lift dramatically the percentage of Europeans inside the total migration program.

That response related to the increased sale of raw materials from Australia to China; the possible sale of pig iron or raw steel from Australia to China; mutual investment between our two industries-that is, investment by China in Australia, particular interest having been shown by China in iron ore, and investment by Australian industry in China's steel industry-and, finally, the mutual interchange of technology. As I said, there were positive responses in each of those matters by the Chinese Premier.

ANSWER.PARA: These things have happened since 9 February: Firstly, as soon as I returned to Australia I had very useful discussions with the industry and the trade unions, and got a very positive response from them.
