QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SOUTH AFRICA: ALLEGED SUPPORT FOR TERRORIST ACTIVITIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs been drawn to a report in today's Sydney Morning Herald, reprinted from the Guardian, describing South African support for terrorist activities in neighbouring Zimbabwe designed to bring about civil chaos and to undermine the economy of that country? How does the continuation of such activities, despite the negotiation of pacts with Angola and Mozambique, affect the Government's evaluation of the South African regime?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —There does seem to be some evidence that South Africa has been involved in activities which are aimed at destabilising the Government in Zimbabwe. I have been informed that while the article which no doubt caught the attention of the honourable member in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning is not an article that we can substantiate, nonetheless a number of facts have been established. Teams of dissidents have been infiltrated into Matabeleland, Zimbabwe, from South Africa, possibly via Botswana. The Zimbabwe Government has labelled the South African supported dissidents 'super-ZAPU' and believes there is a link to Joshua Nkomo, the Zimbabwe African People's Union leader. South Africa probably supported a number of sabotage attacks within Zimbabwe since independence, including the destruction of Air Force planes at Thornhill in 1982 .

ANSWER.PARA: South Africa maintains a special military intelligence unit concerned with Zimbabwe. A radio which broadcasts propaganda to Zimbabwe, Radio Truth, operates from within South African territory. South African involvement in attacks on Zimbabwe's oil pipeline from Beira, Mozambique, and storage facilities at Beira is almost certain. South Africa has delayed the transit of petroleum products to Zimbabwe, and immediately after independence withdrew essential South African- owned rolling stock from Zimbabwe's railways. Zimbabwe is, of course, aware of its vulnerability and it has, in consequence, one expects, prevented the African National Congress from using Zimbabwean territory to operate against South Africa.

In respect of Mozambique, South African supported guerilla activity was directed against Mozambique and was responsible for the disruption and destabilisation of the Government there. On 16 March President Machel and Prime Minister Botha signed the Nkomati Accord, a non-aggression pact, whereby South Africa and Mozambique agreed that neither would allow its territory to be used as a base for acts of aggression or violence against the other. This was followed by talks on economic co-operation. What this does boil down to, however , is that South Africa is utilising policies of destablisation, disruptive policies, on a fairly wide scale in southern Africa and through these is creating marked degrees of instability for a number of the governments in that region. At the same time, it is taking no steps itself to reduce the abhorrent racism and intolerance of the policy of apartheid in its own country.

—Has the Acting Minister for Health seen the recently released report on the drug use habits of New South Wales school children which indicates that 25 per cent of those students surveyed had tried marihuana, that the number of 16 and 17-year-olds drinking alcohol had increased and that more than half the children in the survey had tried sniffing solvents? If the Minister has seen the report, will he advise the House of any action which the Commonwealth is taking or planning to take in response to these alarming findings?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth is very concerned at the result of the survey which covered 4,165 students in New South Wales between year 7 and year 11. A number of other disturbing things came out of the report, indicating that more girls than boys are now smoking regularly, that over half the girls and boys using alcohol are using it on a regular basis and that analgesic usage is high and increasing. As a result of these concerns, the Drug Education Sub-committee and the Health Committee on Drugs of Dependence established a working group to develop a range of educational materials for students, teachers, parents, health educators and community groups to address the solvent abuse problem. Recommended action, which was endorsed by health Ministers, was that additional funds for drug education programs be made available at Commonwealth and State level for International Youth Year. Also we have sought reports from New South Wales as to the action being taken in New South Wales schools to address the problem. But, of course, to state the obvious, it is unlikely that this situation is peculiar to New South Wales. One would certainly expect it to be the case in the other heavy urban concentrations.

ANSWER.PARA: At the national level, the assessment team of the Drug Education Sub-committee has produced its final report on the national drug education program and has made a number of recommendations and findings which will have national implications for drug abuse prevention strategy. These recommendations are currently being considered by State health authorities before referral to all State and territorial health Ministers.

The Commonwealth will continue to give an emphasis through the NDEP to projects directed towards youth in its funding of State and Territory drug education programs in 1984-85. It is a national problem. It is a critical problem and we have to face up to it individually. It is not just something to be left to government. It has to be done at a community level, at a family level. There has to be individual responsibility.

I guess the most logical one is that the growers consider cultivation for a weed kill instead of direct drilling. Apart from that I cannot help the honourable member.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received letters from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) and the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous) proposing that definite matters of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion today. As required by standing order 107 I have selected the matter which, in my opinion, is the most urgent and important and that is that proposed by the Leader of the Opposition namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The continuing alarm and confusion created by the Government's latest blunders on retirement incomes.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is now 355 days since the Hawke Government began breaking its promises to the elderly in our community and to those nearing retirement. We are approaching the anniversary of the May mini-Budget which featured an attack on Australian superannuation conditions. The super slug and the income test on the over-70-year-olds were just the opening shot in a thoughtless and cold-blooded campaign which has caused unprecedented concern among our senior citizens. It is now 260 days since this Government again stood the elderly against the wall by announcing out of the blue the assets test on pensions. Since then we have witnessed a government paying the price for singling out one sector of the community for treatment as second class citizens. It thought that because they were elderly and not given to political activism that it could throw them on to the scrap heap. This is the hallmark, regrettably, of the Government these days. It is not a government of consultation, it is not a government of consensus and that has been confirmed again today at Question Time. Notions such as consultation and consensus are merely empty slogans. It is a government of unconscionable conceit and unconscionable arrogance.

SPEECH.PARA: As I pointed out earlier this week in respect of the Prime Minister's beef and steel fiascos in Japan and China, the only consultation which this Government knows is retrospective consultation. That is what the Government has done in regard to Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and the Government's steel sand castles, and that is what it has imposed on Australia's elderly. It is indeed a very curious method of consultation. First, the Government makes up its mind, by looking at the figures, that it needs more money so that it can continue to spend on a growing public sector. A likely way of feeding Labor's bloated financial appetite is then seized upon. The Government has decided that the pensioners can carry the cost for a new round of public sector growth. Yet it does not bother to see pensioners as anything but figures on a balance sheet. It does not tell them what it is thinking. When the Government's plans come out into the open and begin to become unstuck from day one the Government starts casting about for a quick way out.

Over the past year Australians have witnessed an endless progression of twists and turns by the Hawke Government on the issues of superannuation and the assets test. We have seen open confrontation on this matter between the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The trade union movement made it quite clear that it had not been consulted about the changes relating to superannuation. So that was round one of the Government's retrospective consultation. It has done the same with regard to the assets test. What was announced in the August Budget was shown overnight to be anomalies and full of inequities. It was shown to be unfair and discriminatory.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a disgrace.

—It was an absolute disgrace. No wonder we abolished the assets test in 1976. Labor's proposed test went against the grain of the great majority of Australians. This test put at risk the legitimate aspirations of the people of this nation to work, to get ahead and to provide for a secure retirement. That is not something which I am prepared to see just swept away.

SPEECH.PARA: As we told the Government last year, there were very sound reasons for our abolishing the assets test in existence in 1976. We warned the Government that the sort of assets test it was going to introduce was both costly and complicated to administer, that it would lead to an invasion of privacy and that of its own nature it would be inequitable in operation. In fact, there is evidence that the Government knew the problems before it jumped in. It was none other than the present Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes), the man charged with imposing Labor's assets test, who called it into question last year . Writing in the 1983 edition of Labor Essays, Senator Grimes said:
. . . reimposition of an assets test would fall far short of an ideal solution to problems in this area.

In his essay he pointed to the anomalies, as he also did at the National Economic Summit Conference. But he did not have the numbers in Cabinet so he had to face the music. What followed was another unseemly display of backsliding. The so-called leisure package was announced. It was shown to be discriminatory by the Labor Premier of New South Wales, the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party. Then a variety of other add-ons were floated, but the shilly- shallying had two negative effects. First, the Government's ineptitude only added to the uncertainty and anxiety of the elderly and, second, not surprisingly, it resulted in the emergence of what has been known as 'grey power ' in Australia. The emergence of this group was a direct response to attacks by this Government on the elderly. When the penny dropped that the elderly were preparing to campaign against Labor should it have a premature election, the Prime Minister-not the Minister for Social Security-announced an alleged backdown.

TALK.START.PARA: —Without consultation; not even with his colleagues.
—There was no consultation whatsoever.
—He heard it on the radio.

—Just back from overseas, fresh from his beef and steel fiascos, the Prime Minister used the forum of the National Press Club to announce that the issue would be put in the melting pot again. As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) said, the Minister for Social Security first heard this announcement on the radio. That was another bit of retrospective consultation. The Prime Minister emphasised that there would be an assets test regardless, but that Labor would go back to the drawing boards and look at the issue again.

SPEECH.PARA: What has happened? After months of uncertainty and controversy the Prime Minister's extraordinary announcement served only to guarantee more uncertainty. How would honourable members opposite like to cop that uncertainty? They will be beyond 65 years of age at some given date. They will then be least able to rearrange their affairs. Month after month the elderly have had this uncertainty hanging over their heads, and after 260 days of the Government's incredible and callous ineptitude they are none the wiser and they have no certainty as to whether they will be allowed a pension from this Government. I ask honourable members: Is this fair? Is this the way to treat those least able to rearrange their affairs? Is this indeed the way to govern?

I turn to the Assets Test Review panel led by Professor Gruen and its recommendations. The terms of reference of this assets test panel appointed as the outcome of the Prime Minister's backdown are both restrictive and representative of Labor's approach to the elderly. Instead of taking a comprehensive approach to retirement and the elderly, this Government, despite all the public facade and charade, has treated this growing sector of the community in a grossly ad hoc and piecemeal fashion. It is a classic example of not seeing the wood for the trees.

In yet another step along this path, the Gruen panel of review has been hamstrung by its terms of reference. This has occurred because it cannot look at the overall situation of the elderly. It has been given a fragment of the issue to treat in a vacuum. I wish to make it clear that this is through no fault of the members of the panel. They are doing a task set for them by the Hawke Government. But what will result? Another attempt to piece together a retirement program which is the child of Labor expediency. The latest developments on the assets test demonstrate that this Government is in total disarray on this issue and that it shows no concern for the feeling and anxiety of the older members of our community.

Yesterday we learnt that the panel is considering yet another variation. It is a form of death duty by stealth. We learned that the pension will now be offered as a loan or, as one newspaper reported in a grizzly manner, as a 'pay-as-you- die plan'. I will spell out what that could mean to a man or a women opting for this plan. I will take a person of 65-years of age. I ask honourable members to listen to the consequences of the latest action. Assuming the current long term bond rate of 14 per cent would apply, after just five years under this plan this pensioner would owe the Hawke Government, if it were still in power, over $35, 000. At age 75 years, not an unreasonable age to look forward to living to, that figure would jump to more than $102,000. Should the person reach age 80, which is quite common, under this latest scheme he or she would owe over $232,000. This is outrageous. We pointed out the consequences. And it is still being considered. The figures speak for themselves. The longer a pensioner lives, the more he would owe the Government.

I chose the example of a 65-year-old. What about the case of a 35-year-old invalid pensioner? Would the Government cut off the pension when the money owed exceeded the pensioner's assets? The whole thing is a frightening concept and the discriminatory nature of such a scheme is already evident. Yesterday I asked the Prime Minister to put this scheme down immediately, but he would not. So the concerns and anxiety amongst an extraordinarily significant group of this community are only heightened as a consequence of the dispassionate approach that the Government takes to them, and the Government ought to be condemned for its heartless treatment.

I have mentioned the discriminatory nature of the scheme and how evident this discrimination already is. Once again we would see the elderly in New South Wales, where property values are high, being penalised for living where they do. The pensioners of the capital cities cannot control the forces of the real estate market. They cannot help it that a three-bedroom cottage in Sydney is worth more on the market than one in a country town. Yet, under a scheme such as this they would be the victims and that property differential could result in a loss of pension benefits.

It will be recalled that yesterday I asked the Prime Minister about this very matter. My question went beyond the actual cost to the pensioner's estate itself to the concerns of pensioners and their children over the effects of such a scheme. He acknowledged, honourable members will recall, that the concerns would be there. He acknowledged the concerns it would cause. Yet, he has done nothing to rule it out and the panel is continuing its investigation of a pay-as-you-die plan. If he can see the concerns and the inequities which pensioner groups have and which the Opposition has outlined, why does he not tell the panel that this is not on? What about the example of a person aged 80 owing $232,000? What happens to the family farm? What happens to the small business? What happens to the jobs? The consequences are evident to anyone on this side of the House and the most objective person in the community. But the Prime Minister will not tell the panel to forget such a scheme because the Government is, as he said yesterday, going to consider that scheme. I challenge honourable members opposite to deny it.

Why do they not face the reality of the hardship that others in the community are now going to have to face as a consequence of what the Government has constructed? The Government started out with a totally unfair assets test and out of ineptitude and expediency it will seize another. The Government is now stuck in a quagmire of its own making and in its desperately casting around for a way out it will seize upon anything, irrespective of the consequences to men and women and their families and the children of those families. Obsessed with calling a premature election, the Prime Minister wanted to win back some support . But his credibility with the elderly is in as many pieces as Labor's policies on the elderly are.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, this matter of public importance-

—Madam Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order and seek a ruling from you on the question of ministerial responsibility to this House in respect of providing information. The honourable member for Wakefield asked an important question on the assets test. He wanted to know whether this test would be backdated to last year. He pointed out that this matter had not been made clear. He also pointed out the effects this would have on aged people. I hope that the Minister, recognising his responsibilities, will answer the question in this debate.
—There is no point of order. I call the Minister.
—Where are the other Labor members?

—They know they do not need to come in. Madam Deputy Speaker, this matter of public importance is about the so called 'alarm and confusion created by Government blunders'-which is the wording in the motion-on retirement incomes leading, it is said, 'to the destruction of security in retirement for Australians'. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) described Government policy as thoughtless and cold blooded. I would have thought that if those words had any applicability it would be to the cynicism with which this matter has been brought into the House. The appeal to fear and self-interest is a base element of Liberal political rhetoric as was shown up so appallingly in the House yesterday in the debate on immigration.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us start by examining the claim that the Government has created uncertainty among pensioners over the assets test. Ever since we announced the introduction of the new test it has been the Opposition that has been flitting around the country spreading alarm and confusion as to its impact. As we said, if the Government's original proposals were implemented some 85 per cent of pensioners would be unaffected financially or would gain increased pension entitlement as a result of that test. That is hardly a rational description of the destruction of security in retirement.

It needs to be remembered that age pensions were introduced in Australia as far back as 1908 and there was a test for income and property right until 1976. After certain groups-those over 75 and, later, those over 70-were removed from those means tested, the property test was abolished as from 25 November 1976. In the 1983-84 Budget the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced the Government's intention to reintroduce a means test that takes account of both income and assets for assessing entitlements for pensions. The current asset test proposed in the legislation-the Social Security and Repatriation (Pensions Income and Assets Test) Bill 1983-took account only of income, including some income from assets.

When we introduced the legislation last December, the Opposition, which had the numbers in the Senate, indicated that it would defer its passage until this session. More recently, the Opposition and the Australian Democrats in the Senate have stated that they would defer such legislation again if we attempted to pass it in this session. Our aim, of course, is to provide a system which is fair, equitable and certain.

Let us examine the reasons for the Opposition's actions. In a recent article in the Sydney Morning Herald the true reasons for these actions became apparent. It has nothing to do with genuine concern for pensioners. It is all about attempting, for short sighted political ends, to maintain the alarm and confusion among pensioners for as long as possible for its own political purposes just as it tried to do yesterday and I would have thought it learnt its lesson then. The Sydney Morning Herald said:

The proposal by the Opposition spokesman on social security, Senator Messner, is aimed at maximising the political backlash against the assets test in any early Federal election. Liberal Party tacticians believe that community opposition to the test could quickly dissipate once it was introduced because it is not as draconian as many people believe.

The Opposition is both callous and hypocritical. It has totally failed to produce credible or even intellectually respectable policies and it has to resort to frightening pensioners and old people. It knows full well that the test will have no adverse impact on 85 per cent of pensioners. From their blusterings, members of the Opposition give the impression that all will be.

By contrast, let us have a look at the Government's actions since Budget night in relation to the assets test. On Budget night, 23 August-which, of course, was the date when we announced our intention to consult with pensioners on the test and thus, of course, would lie a logical period for beginning any backdating-and following the first round of consultation, we announced the incorporation of a ' leisure package' into the test on 29 November 1983. That inclusion was a direct result of representations by pensioner organisations. Yet, the Leader of the Opposition coins the phrase 'retrospective consultation'. Following that we financed a further round of consultations in January and February of this year. These were organised by the Australian Council of Social Service-ACOSS-and included nearly all pensioner groups in the country.

Notwithstanding this, there was grave doubt as to whether the form of the assets test proposed gave effect to the principle of directing assistance to the needy in the fairest and most equitable way. For example, it is evident that the leisure package introduced at the behest of the pensioner groups themselves does not now have their support or, if it does have, only highly qualified. This came out of the second round of consultations. It could save some pensioners from having to dispose of property though it will not assist others with assets in shares or banks.

Given the Opposition's stated attitude to defer the legislation again and, in view of this Government's preparedness to consult, we decided to use the additional time available to establish the broadly based panel of community representatives to examine how the Government's principles in this area can best be achieved. Believe it or not-one would not believe it from what the Leader of the Opposition said-this has been supported by the Opposition. Senator Messner told the Senate on 1 March:

The Government has announced that it will refer the whole matter of an assets test to a panel of community based organisations in order to get some better understanding of what it intends. I can only applaud the move at this stage.

What humbug by the Leader of the Opposition! It was completely inconsistent with what his shadow Minister said in the Senate. The panel has been appointed and is undertaking its task. As the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Senator Ryan said in response to questions last week, the Government will be making no decision on the assets test until it has received the panel's report. As was indicated earlier, the Chairman of the panel is Professor Fred Gruen, head of the Economics Department, Research School of Social Sciences at the Australian National University. Other members of the panel-they are not exactly unrepentant socialists to the last man-are: Mark Johnson, Managing Director, the Australian Bank Ltd; Sir William Keys, that notorious far left Trotskyist, National President of the Returned Services League of Australia; Bruce McKenzie, President of the Australian Council of Social Service; Jim Priest, National Secretary of the Australian Pensioners Federation; Philippa Smith, Chairperson of the National Advisory Council on Social Welfare; Dr George Smolicz, Reader in Education at the Adelaide University and a commissioner of the South Australian Ethnic Affairs Commission; Joyce Thurgood, National President of the Association of Civilian Widows; and Ms B. Thyer of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The consultant to the panel is Bruce Paul, Manager of the Actuarial Division, AMP. That does not sound a terribly radical group.

A complaint was made by the now absent Leader of the Opposition about the terms of reference. It seems to me that the Leader of the Opposition cannot have it both ways with the terms of reference. He said the terms of reference were far too limited. Then, when the panel decided to propose alternatives, unacceptable to him, he said that the Prime Minister should intervene to cut down the range of options. The Opposition cannot have it both ways. It cannot say, simultaneously, that the panel has terms of reference which are too narrow and that we have to call them back because they are offering too wide a range of alternatives. The absurdity of that must be apparent even to the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman). The terms of reference read:

Having regard to the principle that the requirements of equity and the demographic fact of the aging of the Australian population require that expenditure on pensions be directed to those most in need, the Review Panel is to consider:
(a) the draft legislation setting out the proposed income and assets test in order to:
(i) identify significant omissions, advantages and disadvantages, anomalies, and/or situations of potential hardship;

(ii) recommend appropriate changes which take account of these problems, bearing in mind the relevant financial implications and the need to minimise the administrative cost and effort to the Government and pensioners; and-
this is the second leg which covers everything else-

(b) alternative mechanisms, bearing in mind the relevant financial implications and the need both to minimise the administrative cost and effort to the Government and pensioners, and to avoid any uncertainty or confusion among pensioners.

In other words, the panel will have to consider the legislation and any alternative mechanisms. It cannot have a broader range of alternatives than that , but the Leader of the Opposition complains about it. Honourable members will be aware that the panel has been given those wide terms of reference.

The Government has the strongest commitment to improving the standard of living of those pensioners without access to private income or assets. Let me illustrate the kind of unfairness that comes into the situation we are trying to deal with in our legislation. I do not understate the difficulties. Honourable members opposite, particularly those who have been in government as Ministers, must be aware, if they remember their oath as Ministers, of the extraordinary difficulties of trying to be fair to the pensioners and also to be equitable to taxpayers. It is essential that we take action, not only after death, against those types of schemes that convert income to capital and enable those smart enough and with enough money to circumvent the existing income test.

The Opposition has claimed that the assets test is inequitable, but there is no doubt that the greatest inequities of all lie in the current income test. Take the case of two people who are neighbours. One is in a public service superannuation scheme and receives his or her benefit as weekly payments and therefore loses fringe benefits and part or all or his or her pension. Next door is a person who contributed the same amount in superannuation and received the same taxation benefits but who receives a lump sum payment and is able to be taxed only on 5 per cent of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Grave robber.
—I warn the honourable member for Denison.

—Through some device, and many of them have blossomed in the community since the assets test was removed, such a person is able to receive, as well as the benefit of the lump sum payment, the full pension and fringe benefits.
—Double dipping.

—Yes, double dipping. Is anyone in the Opposition going to say that that is equitable? Will anyone say that it is just? Is it defensible, even by this spavined Opposition? There are two ways out of it. The first is to provide everyone with a full pension and full fringe benefits. The second it to overcome the situation by encouraging superannuation schemes through lump sum taxation or, however else, to provide weekly superannuation payments. Of course, if we provide people with full fringe benefits and full pensions we can do it in only two ways. The first way is by increasing taxation, because the pensions of today are paid for by the taxpayer of today. The second way leads to what inevitably happens in a scheme such as ours when we try to provide pensions to everyone, regardless of need. The pensions are set at inadequate levels, particularly for the low income people who need them most.

SPEECH.PARA: In the period that we have been in office the maximum rate of pension has increased, whereas in the period of the Liberal Government, between December 1975 and December 1982, pensions declined from 24.4 per cent to 22.6 per cent of average weekly earnings. So let us not have any more humbug about what the Opposition did for the pensioners which tries to give the impression that we have let pensioners' positions decline. There are no welfare policies from honourable members on the other side. Are they prepared to increase pensions to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings? If they are not, they deserve the censure of the House. But there is nothing to indicate what their views are either way. Are they prepared to reverse their callous policy towards all the disadvantaged other than by exploiting them? Are they prepared to do anything for the disadvantaged? I see no evidence of that. What hypocrisy and what a disservice they are doing to the pensioners of this country by now engendering alarm and confusion among a group which deserves sympathy and our support, a group which, history shows, the Opposition does not care about and treats with contempt regarding pensioners as mere election fodder.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the Labor Government, not the Opposition, that is causing the pensioners of this country great worry and concern. That concern has been placed upon them since August, when the Government announced that it would introduce an assets test, for in making that announcement the Government did not spell out the details. When it gave the details there was a huge public uproar, including protests from its own supporters. Now it has sent the assets test off to a committee and it appears that it will be coming back with a totally different proposal from that which it put forward back in August last year.
—That is in the terms of reference.

—It may be in the terms of reference. But the Government is saying that whatever test it introduces will be applied retrospectively to August last year. How then does a widow, feeling that she wants to leave her home and move to live with a relative, know whether she should sell her house and, if she sells it, what she should do with the proceeds? There are hundreds and thousands of Australian pensioners, men and women, who are desperately worried because they cannot plan their affairs and behave in the normal and rational way. Why? Because the Labor Government has put Damocles sword over them and they do not know how that sword will fall, whether it will affect them or their neighbour or not at all. Yet the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones), in making his speech, has said that it is we who have expressed the concern. Why is it that hundreds and thousands of pensioners are tripping into our offices, asking why and how the assets test will operate?

SPEECH.PARA: It is not often that I agree with the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) but he said that the determination to end means test-free pensions and to introduce means tests on assets and the savings of the rest of the 1.8 million pensioners is another kick in the teeth for the aged and retired citizens.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'll bet he hasn't said that since the Labor Government has been in office.

—No, not at all. He said that when in opposition. But, having said one thing, having misled every pensioner in this country, he now supports the Government, which is doing the very reverse. The Minister for Social Security ( Senator Grimes), when in opposition, said:

SPEECH.PARA: If people plan for their retirement they should be able to do so in the expectation that policies will be continued and be consistent.

TALK.START.PARA: —And fair.

—But he said that policies should be continued and consistent. The Government announced an assets test in August. It made the details vague. It is now implied by reports in the Press that a totally different form of assets test will apply. It is quite clear, as was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning, that the recommendations of the committee apparently include proposals for a tougher test than that proposed. Now the Government want to impose a tougher test and make it retrospective. It wants to introduce this crazy scheme whereby people are taxed at death on the pensions they have received. How can every person who has received a pension be sure that a Labor government will not then say on death: 'You have received a pension, though you received it subject to an assets and means test and got the pension as a grant, not as a loan. We have retrospectively reviewed the situation and determined that you or your estate must pay for the pension you received over your lifetime'. That prospect is quite scandalous and the Government has not indicated in any way that that will not happen. Even if it did, no Australian pensioner could trust it and be sure that its promise would be honoured.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister, in his speech, made some comment about the terms of reference given to the committee. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) drew attention to the fact that the terms of reference were very narrow. Indeed, they were very narrow because they point out and require the committee to advise how best to achieve the objectives of ensuring that expenditure on pensions is directed to those most in need. I happen to believe that the most effective way to direct resources to those people in the age bracket most in need is to pay universal pensions and have a sensible and equitable taxation system. It is very interesting to note that in the submissions from the Australian Council of Social Service relating to this whole review of the Government's proposal for the assets test, ACOSS-a body that usually puts great emphasis on needs based assistance-reached the conclusion that there be a total review of the income tax and social security system. The submission stated:

The strong sentiment, virtually unanimous among pensioner groups, was that the Government might better institute a review of the income security system in conjunction with its review of the taxation system. That path of change should yield fewer anomalies than the one chosen.

It is quite clear that the one chosen will yield massive anomalies, a whole succession of anomalies, and at the same time, while those anomalies keep coming out, it means more uncertainty for Australia's elderly citizens. At the end of the terms of reference there was a paragraph which stated that the review panel should consider:

(b) alternative mechanisms, bearing in mind the relevant financial implications and the need both to minimise the administrative cost and effort to the Government and pensioners, and to avoid any uncertainty or confusion among pensioners.

One would think from reading that that it would be possible for the committee to come out in the spirit of what ACOSS said and say: 'Let us look at the whole tax and social security systems'. It may be possible for the committee to look at the situation and say that it would be much more sensible to pay universal benefits to everyone and as a result have people behaving rationally and making sensible investment decisions and having made sensible investment decisions, receive the income and pay tax upon that income, together with their pension income and, in that way, have the whole community behave in retirement as we expect it to behave, as sensible human beings, during the years of participation in the work force.

But no, there was once an Acting Minister for Social Security, the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett). It is quite clear that he, under the line, has given directions to that committee to prevent its reaching that sort of sensible conclusion of paying universal benefits that would tie in with the Labor Government's proposal for a national superannuation scheme. If we paid universal benefits, that would be a threshold and a base upon which to build a national superannuation scheme. What the Minister said to a group campaigning for senior citizens' rights was this:

You are also aware that the Government has proposed to introduce an income and assets test on pensions. Although a panel of community representatives has been established to advise the Government on how this may best be framed, the Government is no less committed to its introduction.

In the social security field the Government is determined to concentrate the resources available on those who are most in need. To do this the Government will proceed with its reforms and will not be deterred by past decisions.

What were they? The past decisions not to go ahead with the originally announced assets test? The Government will not be deterred from those past decisions. So every pensioner in the land should know that there will be an assets test and it may well be tougher than the assets test originally announced. It will be backdated.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the benefits will be equitable.

—The benefits will not be equitable because what the Government will do is rob those people who have endeavoured to make provision for their retirement, those people who have endeavoured to be self-reliant, and penalise them. As a result they will adjust their affairs and the Government will become a government of pawnbrokers. It will seek from pensioners mortgages and other security over their assets. Will it take bills of sale over their watches, jewellery, furniture and refrigerators to pay back the pensions that each Australian, having contributed to the taxation system throughout his life, should be entitled to as a right?

SPEECH.PARA: What we need is a rational retirement scheme for all Australians, not one that penalises those who happen to save in an asset form while at the same time, this Government allows people in other sectors of the community to receive publicly funded pensions paid for by taxpayers who are very often the very people who give it the advice that such an iniquitous assets test should be introduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, may I say once again, very slowly so that those people on the other side can understand the fact: The Gruen Assets Test Review Panel has not finished its deliberations. It has not reported to the Government. The Government cannot respond to a report which it has not received and therefore all the nonsense that has been going on is simply about reports in newspapers on what the panel may or may not do. That is precisely what this matter of public importance is about-the confusion being caused by the Opposition to every single elderly person in this country. I think that the alarm is about the fact that the boys have been found out. In my electorate, after the assets test decision was announced, it was interesting that most of the people I talked to came from one of my neighbouring electorates, an electorate which has been represented by a member who has sat in this Parliament for many years and who in February 1982 opened an office in his electorate for the first time. That is the measure of his concern and heartfelt interest in his electorate, including his older constituents. Because it was left to me to do the explaining, we had lots of Press releases about the confusion being caused to the elderly but we saw not one responsible deed by the representative of that electorate to explain to the members of his electorate precisely what the assets test was about.
—Thank God you are doing some work.

—I did not mind doing it because at least I was accurate. Let us talk about what it is that these honourable members opposite, who are so concerned for the elderly and so outraged about all of this, actually did. The Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) has pointed out that the value of the pension dropped during the Liberal-National Party's time in office. The Minister did not point out but if he will allow me I will point out that inflation rose in that time, further taking away the value of the pension. Did we get anything in return? Certainly we did not. Who suffered during that time? It was the needy who were totally dependent on their pensions, dropping all the time in value and being able to provide fewer of the things needed by pensioners . All kinds of things were going on. We had the Greek conspiracy case, too, which was $8m worth of nonsense. That took away from the pensioners.

SPEECH.PARA: What else took away from the pensioners? The economic recession took away from them because more money had to go out in the unemployment benefit. More unemployment benefit had to be paid as a result of a conscious economic decision of the previous Government. That took away money from that available to increase old age pensions to the level at which they should have been kept, at the level we will take them to. We have the amoeba theory of pension adjustments-if one is spineless or flaccid enough, if one hides far enough behind a murky flow of words, then one can talk about pensions as if one really means something insensible.

I believe the Opposition has demonstrated its capacity to do nothing but cause confusion. It has no intention of doing anything about the situation and its record so far is abysmal. We have all this fake outrage, fake concern and fake policies. But the record is not fake; the record shows very plainly that people really understand what the previous Government was doing. That is why it is now the Opposition.

The assets test was referred to a committee because this Government is committed to the process of consultation. When somebody says a proposition is not what they want, we are quite prepared to talk about it at length. What a contrast to the previous Government. When did it ever consult with anybody but its own friends? Members of that Government were like sheep following Bo Peep, but they lost their Bo Peep and now they do not know where to go. They have totally laughable policies about this, that and the other thing, and none at all about those things that are important. The Opposition calls for a reduction in the deficit but it certainly has no intention of saying where that reduction will take place. Will it come from the outlays that it would make on pensions, one of the biggest outlays in the land? Security for the aged will cost $9.1 billion this year. That amount is bigger than the deficit. Will members of the Opposition cure the deficit by making aged incomes the target to get Budget outlays down?

TALK.START.PARA: —So you are going to tax the elderly?

—Not us; the Opposition wants us to reduce the deficit. Members of the Opposition are very opposed to outlays in growing areas of expenditure. Expenditure on the aged is one of the fastest growing areas because they are a growing section of the population. Blind Freddie could do his sums better than members of the Opposition, and I daresay has in the past. They want to spend more, collect less, reduce the deficit and they want to give it to the pensioners as well. What on earth does this Opposition want to do? The argument is political; that is all it is.

SPEECH.PARA: There is politics in this argument; there is no purpose in it. The Opposition did the same with immigration. Honourable members opposite deliberately set up questions implying racism. They know that consultation is a lengthy process, but they seize opportunities with nasty glee to make divisions in our community. They cannot stand the notion that this Government is in power because it offered consensus, because the public voted for consensus and it wants consultation. They behave like a lot of disruptive, hating, nasty little boys. I say that with some passion. I am tired of sitting here and looking at some of the grade 6 behaviour we get.

The Opposition does not care who gets hurt in the process of their nasty little political opportunistic operations or who was offended by the nonsense they went on with yesterday. All they want to do is see whether they can find a vote from anyone at all, no matter what they have to do to get it. The former Treasurer believes in the assets test-he is on record about that-but the previous Goverment stepped back from the test in place and left a vacuum because the problem was put into the too hard basket. As to superannuation, the superannuation tax cost $2.5m for coverage of 45 per cent of the work force. The benefits are being wasted, as everybody knows. The bigger the scheme and the richer you are, the more you get. Is that equity; is that fair; is that looking after the needy? It is regressive in its operation and we have to do something to make it more sensible.

The matter of public importance refers also to blunders. Let us have a look at a few blunders. During the time of the previous Government pensions dropped from 24 per cent of average weekly earnings to 22 per cent of average weekly earnings . Was that a blunder or was it intentional? Inflation rose, severely cutting into the value of the pension. Was that intentional or was it a blunder? The health insurance confusion upset absolutely everybody in the community, including aged people. Was that intentional or was it a blunder? Members of that Government sent the economy into deep recession. Was that intentional or just a blunder? They created the highest level of unemployment in this country since the 1930s, depriving age pensioners of the opportunity to have a better pension. Was that intentional or was it a blunder?

What are we talking about here? Are we talking about a Government that has to correct anomalies which were created by the spinelessness of the present Opposition and which, in doing so, will consult the people involved however long that consultation takes, or are we talking about an Opposition which is a pack of political opportunists who will hurt anybody at all in their mad ambition to get back to where they were, where they can sit back doing nothing, hoping that somebody will lead them. I do not believe that nine-tenths of the elderly people in this country believe that they were better off under the previous Government. I will say one thing: The previous Government certainly treated age pensioners fairly badly. I was in an elderly citizens centre when a Liberal candidate for one of the local seats marched in with a handful of material to be letterboxed. He dumped it in that centre with the understanding, without even asking, that those people would go and letterbox it for him because, after all, people over 65 years of age are naturally Liberal voters. That is not quite right, as he found out in 1983 and as he will find out again whenever it is that he has to try it again.

The passage of the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Act 1983 heralded the most significant changes to our electoral legislation for fifty years. As part of the Government's continuing commitment to electoral reform, it now undertakes to bring referendum legislation into line with the new Electoral Act, to make provision for voting at referendums for electors in the Territories , and to incorporate certain other necessary modifications to current procedures .

The changes are largely of a machinery nature, and will simplify the administration of referendums, particularly when they are held concurrently with elections. The most appropriate approach, is to repeal the Referendum ( Constitution Alteration) Act 1906 and subsequent amending Acts and to replace them with a new Act.

The new Electoral Act has removed or brought up to date many outmoded provisions; it has removed certain anomalies; it has extended the right, and in the case of Aboriginals the obligation to enrol and to vote; it has made it easier for electors to get on the rolls and stay on the rolls; and it has altered polling procedures to make voting more accessible to previously disadvantaged groups. Hence overseas electors, itinerant workers and Antarctic electors may now register a vote. Electors may vote as ordinary voters at any polling booth within their division instead of only within their subdivision. Mobile polling facilities will be provided in the outback and for patients in hospitals and similar institutions. A register of postal voters will be established so that people in remote areas or people unable to attend polling booths can be sent an application for a postal vote immediately an election is announced. This Bill ensures that the worthwhile reforms enshrined in the new Electoral Act will also streamline voting procedures at future referendums. In addition this Bill makes other changes to our referendum legislation.

The current Act provides that 'Yes' and 'No' cases be submitted within four weeks after the passage through the Parliament of the proposed law. Then, within two months of the four weeks and not later than two weeks after the issue of the writ, pamphlets must be printed and posted to each elector. These provisions can mean that the pamphlets may reach electors months in advance of voting day for the referendum. They should be replaced by a requirement that the Electoral Commissioner simply despatch the yes/no pamphlets not later than 14 days before voting day. The requirement should also be extended to cases where a Bill is passed by one House only. At present, the Electoral Commissioner is not under legal duty under the Act to print and distribute the yes/no pamphlets where the Government postpones or cancels a referendum. It is highly desirable that it be expressly stated in the new Act that this is the case.

The new provisions in the Commonwealth Electoral Act relating to disclosure of electoral expenditure apply to parties, candidates and groups of candidates; persons acting without the written authority of parties, candidates and groups; and publishers, broadcasters and printers. The Government is of the view that for referendums there should be a provision requiring that returns of expenditure be lodged only by publishers, broadcasters and printers. These returns will indicate the major sources of referendum expenditure. It would be consistent with the electoral provisions for the referendum period for which returns must be lodged to be from the date of issue of the writ to voting day for the referendum. In addition, the electoral provisions relating to the disclosure of donations to political parties and candidates are not readily translatable to referendums. Referendum donations do not give rise to potential corruption in the way that undisclosed election donations might. Therefore there is little point in requiring their disclosure.

Members will be aware that in the last 12 months the Government has demonstrated its concern for and interest in electoral matters. The legislation which I am now putting before honourable members should be considered against this background of concern. The Government believes that the changes proposed to the machinery for conducting referendums are timely and sensible, following the passage of the new electoral legislation, yet at the same time preserving the basic elements and broad principles which are already at the heart of the current system. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The main purpose of this Bill is to amend the Australian National University Act 1946 in order to remove provisions inserted in the Act in 1979 and 1981 which restrict the activities of student organisations in the university. In addition to this primary purpose, the Bill provides for a number of minor amendments to the Act, most of which have been requested by the university.

The amendments made to the Australian National University Act in 1979 and 1981 by the Fraser Government were directed at restricting the ways in which fees levied on students for the provision of amenities and services could be used. An objective was to prevent these fees being used for so-called socio-political purposes, including affiliation by a student association with a national association of students.

These restrictions involve an unwarranted intrusion into the internal affairs of the university. Students should be free to make decisions about how they run their organisations subject to their accountability to the governing body of the university. A wide range of student activities should be a normal feature of campus life. It is for the Council of the Australian National University to decide, not the Government, what are appropriate uses for funds levied to provide amenities and services. To impose restrictions of this nature represents an unacceptable limitation on the proper autonomy of the Council as the governing body of the university.

It is the Government's intention to repeal the restrictions brought into the Act in 1979 and 1981 so that the Act in the area of funding amenities and services for students will return to the situation existing prior to the 1979 amendments. The Council of the University has been consulted and has indicated that it welcomes the action the Government is taking. It will again be the responsibility of the Council to supervise the use of these funds as an aspect of its general responsibility for the governance of the university.

The Bill also provides for a number of minor amendments to the Australian National University Act. The Bill removes from the Act the provision for an annual appropriation of $650,000 for the university. This provision goes back to the establishment of the university in 1946 but has been overtaken by time. As the annual appropriation for the university for running expenses is now of the order of $121m, it is sensible to remove this anachronism from the Act and to add this amount to the funds appropriated each year for the university.

A number of amendments requested by the university are included in the Bill. These include the removal of sex-discriminatory language from the Act, the addition of student representation to the Board of the Institute of Advanced Studies, the establishment of the position of Treasurer as an office of the university, and the up-dating of penalties for traffic offences on university land. The Bill gives the university power to make statutes authorising the disposal of vehicles abandoned on university land after reasonable efforts have been made to trace their owners.

The opportunity is also being taken to make some formal amendments to the Australian National University Act and to bring this Act into line with current legislative practice in several matters. These are the provision for disclosure of interests by members of the University Council and for disqualification of a member of Council.

The Bill has no implications for Commonwealth funding of the ANU. Fees for amenities and services are levied from students by the University Council at rates approved by the Council and do not involve Commonwealth expenditure. This Bill gives effect to a principle of considerable importance in defining the respective roles of government and university governing bodies in the management of institutions. It embraces a broad concept of the nature and value of a university education. I commend the Bill to the House.
