DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER HERITAGE (INTERIM PROTECTION) BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Holding, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill has two main purposes: To preserve and protect areas in Australia and Australian waters which are of particular significance to Aboriginals or Islanders in accordance with their traditions; and to preserve and protect objects, including Aboriginal and Islander human remains, which are of particular significance to Aboriginals or Islanders in accordance with their traditions. It will fill a gap in the law of Australia which can allow sites of significance to be damaged, destroyed or desecrated, and can allow objects of significance, including Aboriginal human remains, to be traded, displayed and otherwise used in ways which are anathema to Aboriginals and their traditions.

The need for legislation to enable direct, immediate action by the Commonwealth has been highlighted by such events as Noonkanbah and a number of situations which have arisen during the life of this Government. Time and again the Commonwealth has been powerless to take legal action where State or Territory laws were inadequate, not enforced or non-existent, despite its clear constitutional responsibility. Occasionally there has been enough good will to deter people from proceedings in ways inconsistent with Aboriginal traditions and wishes. But good will is not always sufficient. The time for legislative action by the Commonwealth has come. In the eyes of Aboriginals such action is long overdue. They have stressed to me the need for priority to be given to enacting legislation which can counter the real, and at times sudden, threats which are made to significant sites and objects. They have asked the Government to provide a means for arriving at solutions to important and often emotionally charged problems.

This Bill is an answer to those requests. It will give the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs power to protect and preserve areas and objects from injury or desecration. Such injury or desecration encompasses a range of activity. For example, the construction of a road through or near a significant Aboriginal area, entry by tourists to such an area in a way inconsistent with the entry restrictions of local Aboriginal tradition, or the construction of a dam near to such an area which will result in the inundation of that area, may each constitute injury or desecration of a particular significant Aboriginal area. In the case of a significant Aboriginal object, physical mutilation as well as public display of or commercial dealing with the object may constitute injury or desecration.

This Bill is the first part of a legislative scheme which this Government intends to enact to ensure the preservation and protection of the cultural heritage of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians. That scheme will give the Commonwealth Government a legislative framework in which to exercise the constitutional power and responsibility clearly to the Commonwealth by the overwhelming majority of Australians in the 1967 referendum. This Government has shown itself willing to take on that responsibility and to act seriously in exercising it. The Bill before the House is further evidence of the Government's acceptance of that responsibility.

As I have mentioned previously in this House, model land rights legislation is being prepared in consultation with Aboriginals throughout Australia. In the same way, the Bill before the House today has been prepared in response to requests from Aboriginal people and following consultation with them. State Governments and the mining and pastoral industries have also been given an opportunity to comment on the Bill. Whilst I acknowledge that there has been some criticism of the time period in which comments were sought, it did nevertheless provide an opportunity which certain states have not been prepared to give the Commonwealth in relation to legislation prepared by those States impinging on matters for which the Commonwealth has a clear responsibility. It is an interim measure which will be replaced by more comprehensive legislation dealing with Aboriginal land rights and heritage protection. As evidence of the Government's intention to legislate more comprehensively, the Bill before the House is expressed to have effect for no more than two years from the date of its commencement.

I must make it clear from the outset that this is not interim land rights legislation nor is it intended to be an alternative to land claim procedures. I will not be making declarations with respect to vast areas of land in de facto recognition of a claim which Aboriginals may wish to make later under another law. The Bill speaks of significant Aboriginal areas, and defines 'area' to include a site. The use of the word 'area' rather than site will allow flexibility in recognising what Aboriginals believe to be significant. It will save a narrow and artificial approach being taken to sites, for example, to discrete geological formations. Where a site is particularly secret and sacred there may be an area immediately adjacent to it where people ought not to go. Transgression of that space may be as offensive as entry to the site. It may also be thought to place people going there in physical danger. This Bill is worded to enable those situations to be accommodated. It is not meant to close off huge areas. It will not be administered in that way.
Scheme of protection
The scheme of the Bill is a simple one, aimed at granting effective protection to areas and objects under threat of injury or desecration. Its key features are as follows:
1. Action will be taken only when the Minister has received an application by or on behalf of Aboriginals or Torres Strait Islander people.
2. The Minister will need to be satisfied that the area or object for which protection is sought is significant in accordance with Aboriginal tradition.

3. When deciding whether to make a declaration in respect of an area or object the Minister will take into account such other matters as he considers relevant. This will allow the weighing of competing interests in each case.

4. Where a declaration may be made in respect of an area for a period of more than 30 days, the Minister will be obliged to receive and consider a report prepared by an independent person dealing with the range of issues that such an application may raise. These include the type and extent of any protection which should be granted and the effects which the making of a declaration may have on the proprietary interests of persons other than the Aboriginal applicants.

5. Declarations will set out particulars of the area or object to be protected. They will also contain provisions for and in relation to the protection or preservation of the area or object from injury or desecration. The Bill recognises that because areas vary in physical form and significance and size, different conditions may need to be applied to each. Because the types of activities which may be permitted on such areas will vary in accordance with local Aboriginal traditions, the activities governed by the declarations may also vary. For example, entry to an area may be unrestricted in one case and closely prescribed in another, depending on traditional rules governing access. Similar comments can be made with respect to siginficant Aboriginal objects. As I mentioned earlier, while physical mutilation will clearly constitute injury or desecration of an object, the public display of or an attempt to sell such an object may be equally offensive in some cases. The provisions of declarations will be drafted bearing these things in mind.

6. Where Aboriginal human remains are involved, the Minister will be empowered to order the delivery of those remains to himself or to Aboriginal people entitled to them, and willing to accept responsibility for them, in accordance with Aboriginal tradition. This provision will enable the satisfactory disposal of remains held contrary to expressed Aboriginal wishes. Consistent with the requirements of the Constitution, where this, or any other action under the Act, involves the acquisition of property, compensation will be payable to the person whose property is acquired.

7. Before making a declaration, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs will be obliged to consult his State or Territory counterpart to ascertain whether the law of that State or Territory offers effective protection. If it does, a declaration will not be necessary. I will refer to the relationship between this legislation and State and Territory laws in more detail later in this speech.

8. A declaration will be published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette and in local newspapers. It will take effect from the date of publication in the Gazette or a later date specified in the declaration. Reasonable steps will be taken to give written notice of a declaration to persons likely to be substantially affected by it. This will include advice to the relevant State or Territory government.

9. Declarations will be treated in many respects like regulations. For example, a declaration will be laid before each House of this Parliament within 15 sitting days after it has been made. Either House may disallow the declaration within the statutory period. Review by the Houses of Parliament will, in effect, be the only review of the merits of a Minister's decision to make a declaration. Of course, other administrative law remedies will still be available to people affected by the declaration.

10. In some emergency situations, where the Minister is unavailable to make a declaration according to the formal requirements of the Bill, an authorised officer will be able to make an urgent declaration which will remain in effect for no more than 48 hours.
State and Territory Laws

As I have already said, this Bill provides the legal basis upon which the Commonwealth can act where the law of a State or Territory does not provide the necessary protection. The lack of protection may arise from either an absence of effective legislation or an unwillingness to enforce the provisions of legislation capable of meeting the goals of this Bill. The Commonwealth is not attempting to cover the legislative field in this area of heritage protection. The Bill expresses an intention not to exclude or limit the operation of a law of a State or Territory that is capable of operating concurrently with it. In practice the Commonwealth sees this as legislation to be used as a last resort. The processes for the making and continuation of declarations will ensure that full recognition will be given to relevant State and Territory laws, and co- operation will be sought from State and Territory governments.

Where the Minister is considering whether to make a declaration in relation to an area, an object or a class of objects, he will be obliged to consult the relevant State or Territory to ascertain whether there is effective protection of the area, object or objects. In the case of Norfolk Island he will consult the relevant Executive member. By reference to long-standing convention, he will consult the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) where the Australian Capital Territory or an external Territory, other than Norfolk Island , is concerned.

Although the Minister will be obliged to consult in this way, the mere failure to consult will not invalidate any declaration he may make. Let me assure the House that all reasonable attempts will be made to consult State and Territory colleagues. On occasions the relevant Minister may be unavailable to discuss the matter, and the urgency of the threat to the area or object may be such that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs must take a decision without the benefit of such consultation. There may be occasions when a State or Territory Minister will refuse to consult. This Bill is framed to ensure that such refusal will not frustrate its proper operation.

Where a State or Territory has no law capable of providing effective protection , or no action is being taken to give effect to that law, the Commonwealth will act in appropriate cases. It is open to the States to ensure that effective heritage protection is offered by their legislation. It is possible that State or Territory law may be capable of providing protection, but not with the same speed as Commonwealth law. The Bill provides that, in such a case, the Minister may make a declaration. Where, in that or other circumstances, the Minister is later satisfied that a State or Territory law does effectively provide protection to the subject matter of a declaration, he must revoke that declaration.

The rights of individuals under concurrently operating laws will also be preserved. Where a person may be prosecuted and convicted under this Act or a law of a State or Territory, nothing in this Act will render that person liable to be punished more than once in respect of the same act or omission. Nothing in this Bill will derogate from rights which a person may have to any remedy apart from this Act.

It will be clear from this summary that the Commonwealth wants to encourage States and Territories to use such legislation as they have in the interests of the Aboriginal and Islander people for whose benefit it was passed. Where that legislation is inadequate the Commonwealth will, through this legislation, encourage changes to be made. The Bill before the House is intended to meet those situations where, for whatever reason, local law is inadequate. The Commonwealth has a clear constitutional responsibility to act. This Bill will give it a legislative base on which to act.
Enforcement and Penalties

The major offences which this Bill creates are breaches of the provisions of declarations. For example, it will not be an offence under this legislation to desecrate a significant Aboriginal area unless there has been a declaration in respect of it and the activity complained of is in breach of that declaration. Thus, where the Minister has made a declaration containing provisions for the protection of an area from injury or desecration, and an individual person or a corporation knowingly contravenes a provision, that person or corporation will be guilty of an offence. A similar scheme will have effect in respect of significant Aboriginal objects.

The high penalties which this Bill sets out for breaches of declarations are an indication of the seriousness with which this Government views the need for heritage protection. The desecration of a site or object can strike at the very roots of Aboriginal beliefs and observances. We hope that, as declarations are made, those whose activities may be impeded or whose interests may be affected will respect the interests of the relevant Aboriginals or Islanders and observe the terms of the declarations. At the very least, the possibility of substantial financial penalties and imprisonment should act as a deterrent to those contemplating acting contrary to a declaration. No longer will it be a cheap option to destroy a site or sell an object.

Where people are willing to proceed in defiance of a provision or a declaration , injunctions and interim injunctions can be sought from the Federal Court of Australia by the Minister. The range of conduct which may be subject to an injunction is widely drawn, as is the power of the Court to restrain a person from engaging in certain conduct or to require him to do something. Company directors and employees will need to look closely at their position under this Bill. The intention of a member of the governing body, a director, servant or agent of a body corporate, or the knowledge of that person, will be deemed to be the intention or knowledge of the body corporate. Conduct engaged in by any individual on behalf of a body corporate shall be deemed to have been engaged in also by the body corporate. I reiterate the hope that this legislation will promote genuine attempts to resolve conflicts which may occur in this area.

The Bill recognises that, in judicial proceedings arising under it, there may be occasions when it will be necessary for evidence to be given concerning a secret or sacred aspect of Aboriginal tradition. Where this is the case, people may be reluctant to give such evidence in proceedings which are open to the public and which may be reported. Experience in Aboriginal land claim hearings in the Northern Territory has shown the benefit to the Aboriginal Land Commissioner and parties appearing before him of enabling Aboriginal people to give some evidence on a restricted basis. This Bill will enable courts to adopt a similar approach. It is a further measure to ensure that the secrecy attaching to matters of particular significance to Aboriginals and Islanders is respected.
Conciliation

To encourage attempts at the resolution of conflict, the Bill provides that, where the Minister has received an application for a declaration, he may request such people as he considers appropriate to consult, to consult either him or his nominee. This consultation could precede or follow the making of a declaration. Where a declaration has been made, the resolution of the matter to the satisfaction of the applicant and the Minister may result in the revocation or variation of the declaration. Where there is resolution of the matter before the Minister has made a declaration there may be no need for a declaration, or a declaration may contain different provisions from those it might otherwise have contained.

Furthermore, the Bill provides for the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) to authorise grants of legal or financial assistance to people who wish to apply for a declaration, whose proprietary interests have been or may be adversely affected by a declaration, or against whom legal proceedings have been instituted. In considering an application, the Attorney-General, or an officer authorised by him, will need to be satisfied that it would involve hardship to the person to refuse the application, and that all the circumstances make it reasonable for a grant to be made.
Conclusion

This will be beneficial legislation, as other legislation remedying social disadvantage has been. Aboriginals and Islanders will be secure in the knowledge that areas and objects of particular significance to them can be preserved and protected. Where the remains of ancestors were stolen from graves and shamefully abused, this Bill will allow those remains to be returned to them. Mr Justice Murphy recently observed as part of the High Court's judgment in the Tasmanian dams case:

The history of the Aboriginal people of Australia since European settlement, is that they have been the subject of unprovoked aggression, conquest, pillage, rape, brutalization, attempted genocide and systematic and unsystematic destruction of their culture.

This Bill is an exercise of a Commonwealth constitutional power aimed at preserving what has survived that process. It falls within the kind of benefit which such laws may properly confer. But the benefit will not be confined to those local Aboriginals and Islanders whose areas and objects receive the direct protection of the law. In a wider and very real sense, the benefit will be felt by the whole community. The preservation and protection of this ancient and significant culture from the destructive processes which have been operating at different rates across this country can only enrich the heritage of all Australians. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Porter) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILL:
INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT (INCOME EQUALIZATION DEPOSITS) BILL 1984]
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate on this Bill is resumed, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill and the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Income Equalization Deposits) Bill 1984.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, before the suspension of the sitting for lunch I began speaking on the Loan (Income Equalization Deposits) Amendment Bill and cognate Bill by quoting from a policy speech made by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). To remind honourable members of that short quote, I will repeat it. In Griffith early last year, Mr Kerin said:

SPEECH.PARA: Farmers can rest assured that they will lose nothing under Labor and stand to gain much.

Following that, I pointed out to the House that farmers have lost many things and have not gained much, unless the Government intends to claim credit for the breaking of the drought. As I mentioned, the proposal before the House to amend the Loan (Income Equalization Deposits) Act ignores completely the fluctuating nature of primary producers' incomes. It may be hard for some honourable members who have not had experience of this to realise that it is nothing for a primary producer to find that one year he has a negative income and the next year he may have quite a good income. Without measures such as the income equalisation deposits scheme, many primary producers can find themselves in a position of paying more tax than a person on a steady income.

This proposal amounts to an emasculation of the whole IED scheme and is just another example of the Australian Labor Party's attack on primary producers. Furthermore, this proposal does not have the support of farmers or farm leaders. Both the National Farmers Federation and the Victorian Farmers and Graziers Association have spoken very strongly against this and, as the honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh) mentioned, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has had it drawn to his attention. The amendment moved by the Opposition does take into account the problems of primary producers' fluctuating incomes and it also removes any of the inequities about which the Government seems to be very concerned.

The point to be remembered about this proposed scheme is that when a farmer does have a good year, which is certainly not every year, by the time he has paid his income tax and his provisional tax, and probably has tried to catch up on a bit of deferred maintenance, he will not have any money left to use this so -called income equalisation deposits scheme, as proposed by the Government, whereas the Opposition's amendment proposes that any deductions for the purposes of deposit under the income equalisation deposit scheme would be fully tax deductible in the year of deposit. Furthermore, interest would be paid on the investment component of that deduction. In other words, the equivalent of the tax payable would not earn any income. Interest would be paid at a rate of 9.5 per cent and of course when the primary producer withdrew the deposit it would be counted as fully taxable income.
I suggest that the government's proposal will not have the support of primary producers as individuals, and certainly not of their organisations.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the Government's proposal.

—That is correct, the Government's proposal. As I have said before, I doubt that it will get sufficient support even to pay for the administration costs. I think the whole thing will be quietly forgotten in the years to come. The problem with the proposed scheme is that it removes any flexibility that a primary producer might have if he tends to use the scheme. It does not have any regard for the primary producer's fluctuating income. It will have little support and I suggest it is fairly useless. Furthermore, I think the name ' income equalisation deposit' is certainly no longer relevant because it is not that at all; it is just some form of high yielding government bond. We might even call it the inflexible useless deposits scheme. So I suggest that the Government would do well to accept the Opposition's amendment in good faith because I believe it is a fair and sound proposal and it would be very well supported by all primary producers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In pursuing this debate and supporting the Loan (Income Equalization Deposits) Amendment Bill, let me say that the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) made some remarks about the general context within which primary producers fall. I am pleased that he has because it is important in the conduct of a debate of this nature to look at the framework within which an income equalisation deposits scheme would fall. The economic framework at this stage is reasonably promising and certainly in terms of the figures we have before us it is reasonably promising.

SPEECH.PARA: Talking in specific terms about the current arrangements, as previous speakers have said, this Bill is designed to enable bona fide primary producers to engage in depositing their money in years when their incomes are high to provide funds which can be drawn when incomes are lower. It is important to spell out at this point that there is an incentive for primary producers to make these deposits. These deposits will obtain an interest rate set quarterly at 2 percentage points above the short term Commonwealth Treasury bond rate. That is a fairly attractive interest rate. In terms of the general earnings on the funds that are being deposited, I do not believe that that is an unattractive rate of interest. I suggest to the honourable member for Wannon that if we are looking at it in terms of an interest rate, that is a reasonable return on funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you can get a better rate elsewhere.

—The honourable member for Wannon says that one can get better interest rates elsewhere. Of course, if one wants to deal in the prime market that is always possible, but if we are to deal quite specifically, it is not the intention of primary producers to go into speculative market activity with respect to short term money market operations; it is the intention of primary producers, I would think, to produce a substantial product from which they earn an attractive income. We are pleased that they do. We are offering them a scheme which, when they do earn an attractive income, one which may be substantially high, they can deposit that at an attractive interest rate. That interest rate is set on a quarterly basis two percentage points above the Commonwealth bond rate. That clearly is not the peak rate of interest. The honourable member for Wannon is really asking us to offer to primary producers the peak rate of interest for engaging in a non-speculative activity when in fact the peak rate of interest applies only to those engaged in speculative activity. The honourable member for Wannon cannot have it both ways. A bona fide primary producer cannot at the same time be somebody who is engaging in short term money market operations.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are to engage in the possibility of some income adjustment activity it is not at the same time possible to say: 'Well, now, I want to go out and become a short term money market operator and earn the highest rate of interest'. I think the Opposition has to face up to that in view of the fact that we are talking about a situation of equity and fairness in government policy. The Opposition cannot ask for both. I will talk about that in just a moment because some statistics suggest the degree of inequity.

In all fairness to the honourable member for Wannon I say that if he is engaging in a desire to get peak interest rates, by all means he should go into the speculative money market, but he should not call himself a primary producer and expect to engage in income equalisation deposit arrangements and get that sort of coverage. I am suggesting that it is important to recognise one's basic definition. In this context we are saying that we will continue with the scheme. I make another point which I think is relevant in the context of this debate. At the current time there is probably only one primary industry which can really take advantage of this, because its producers are earning high incomes; that is the wheat industry. That is recognised. Other industries, such as the sugar industry, are finding that their current income performance would not enable them to take advantage of the scheme. We on this side recognise that; at the same time we recognise that their inability to take advantage of an income equalisation deposit arrangement will depend on the economic performance of that industry.

To some extent-I will talk a little further about this in a moment-that economic performance depends upon international market factors as well as domestic production factors and costs. That leads me to say that I think if we are talking about the performance of various sectors of primary industry there are reasons for saying that industry in general is better off. I am not going to talk about the breaking of the drought, because obviously that is an external factor. One might want to claim that the breaking of the drought had something to do with the arrival of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the Lodge. There are other factors that do suggest that if we can win major sporting events and get the economy performing perhaps the Prime Minister is not beyond events of that supernatural quality, but that would be beyond the scope of this debate. What we do want to say is that in the context of setting an economic framework it is clear that the rate of inflation has been reduced under this Government. That is a substantial performance because in the primary sector inflation can be a very difficult thing to cope with. But the rate of inflation has been reduced. Of course, in the last quarter it in fact fell by 0.4 per cent. In terms of cost pressures, primary producers are now better off than they were under the previous Government. Let us not make any bones about that.

Cost reductions provide a benefit to primary producers. They flow through with respect to export markets. We on this side are conscious that it is very difficult when dealing with an export market and when prices are determined by international factors to deal with a continually rising cost base in terms of domestic inflation and wages. But I suggest in the context of this debate and this Bill that at the present time primary producers in general are better off than they were before we came into office, because we have reduced inflation. At the same time, arising from that reduction there has been a reduction in wage pressures. I am conscious of the fact that wage pressures represent a cost to primary producers, but I suggest that the performances of the 4.3 per cent and the 4.1 per cent national wage increases were substantially better performances in terms of the kind of assistance that industry like this might need. So we have the score on the board there.

I think something else has to be added in the context of this debate and that is that interest rates have fallen. If we consider the cost position that primary producers are facing, we see that there has been a substantial decrease in interest rates under this Government. That has been due not only to the successful acceptance of the deficit in the last Budget, but also to market factors. But the combination of a reduction in deficit pressure and the facts that our Budget and the prices and incomes accord were accepted and that the National Economic Summit Conference laid a foundation of confidence has meant that we now have a lower rate of inflation, lower rates of wage increases and lower interest rates.

That all suggests that, in terms of a macroeconomic picture, primary producers are facing a better condition than they were prior to our coming into government . I have already mentioned that the breaking of the drought is obviously good news. It is good news for everyone and we are as pleased as the other side. But to talk in terms of the bad deal primary producers have got under this Government just does not add up because in fact the economic framework is substantially better than it was before we came into office. I believe that we have done a great deal to restore a degree of stability.

I think it is important for me to talk in terms of equity because obviously speakers in this debate will talk about it. One of the claims made is that under this arrangement we are not allowing people to earn the maximum market interest rate as a result of their main deposit from this income equalisation deposit arrangement. If we consider what has happened to taxes in the past we see quite clearly that a great degree of inequity developed in the tax system. It has to be said to members of the Opposition that they have to take this on board. Between 1976-77 and 1981-82 the percentage of tax paid by individuals, that is people on pay-as-you-earn taxes, went up from 61.03 per cent of all taxes collected to 65.77 per cent of all taxes collected. In other words, the ordinary Australian citizen-remember in this Bill we are talking about equity as one criterion-has had the experience under the previous Government of bearing this substantial increase in taxes. It is very hard for people in the Opposition to come into this place during this debate and say that we are not proceeding on the basis of equity because the figures do not work for them; they work against them.

Where was the decrease in taxes being paid? There was a small decrease with respect to company tax. It fell from 20.21 per cent in 1976-77 to 19.08 per cent in 1981-82. Thus there was a small decline in company taxation, largely, incidentally, as a result of the recession that the Opposition brought on. The economic vandals who are now in the Opposition brought on a substantial recession. As a consequence of that vandalism the percentage of company taxes fell. The area in which taxes did fall was in other payments by individuals. Other payments fell from 18.07 per cent in 1976-77 to 14.38 per cent in 1981-82. We know how that decrease came about. It was due to tax avoidance and the schemes that were dealt out. This Bill specifically addresses itself to the need to eliminate tax avoidance. No one is coming into this place and saying that tax rorts have been practised by primary producers, but we are saying that tax rorts were practised when the Opposition was in government.

What we are trying to do with respect to this legislation is eliminate that possibility. No one is pointing the finger and saying that primary producers are into tax rorts. We are saying that this legislation recognises the possibility. If people are going to come into this place and talk in terms of equity, it must be recognised that, quite clearly, the pay-as-you-earn taxpayers were those who suffered under the previous Government. Those who, in fact, got the worst deal were ordinary Australian citizens. It is no good coming into this place saying that this Bill is bad news for primary producers because, in fact, as I have indicated, the macroeconomical framework has improved. There has been a reduction in inflation, in interest rates and in wages pressure. Along with the breaking of the drought, all of these factors have contributed to a substantial improvement in the kinds of circumstances that confront primary producers.

We, as well as the Opposition, are pleased about that, but we cannot avoid the reality that primary producers are facing a better macro-economic picture than was evident when we came into office. Part of that damaged macroeconomic picture had to do with the failed policies of the person who preceded the honourable member in the seat of Wannon and the present honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). I think that has to be said.

In conclusion, one final point needs to be made. When one talks about income equalisation, one can make a very strong case for saying that we should look at income equalisation for professional athletes. I am very conscious that the people who suffer greatly in terms of income equalisation are those with a very short earning career, particularly in professional sports such as Australian rules football, rugby league and cricket. I refer to people such as Dennis Lillee and Rodney Marsh. People who compete in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane and other cities in Australia do need to have some capacity to equalise their income because they have a very short earning span and a very high income. Often they have earned a relatively low income prior to getting into that role and after that role. So one can make a good case for extending income equalisation to professional sports people. We would be doing them a favour. That is the sort of issue which I think we on this side of the House will be taking up. I am pleased to support the Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address the attention of the House to the Loan (Income Equalization Deposits) Amendment Bill. I make the point to the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) that his speech smacked of the remarks of one of his predecessors, who once suggested to farmers that not only were things getting better but that they had never had it so good. I point out to the honourable member that the rural picture is not at all the picture that he painted here this afternoon. In reality, the farmers across Australia have not seen an increase in unit income. Even the grain farmers, who the honourable member said have had a remarkably good year, have not had an increase in unit income. There has not been an increase in the price per tonne of grain; there has been an increase only in the volume of grain delivered. That increase, of course, reflects the vagaries of the seasons and, for those who would accept it, the intervention of divine providence.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality with which the honourable member for Stirling must come to grips is that farm incomes over the drought period fell by between 50 per cent and 75 per cent. What would have been the reaction of the honourable member's friends in the Australian Council of Trade Unions if their incomes had fallen similarly by 50 per cent to 75 per cent? The honourable member said, as did other speakers from the Government, that the Australian Labor Party's excuse for introducing the Bill was to minimise the tax avoidance that was occurring under the income equalisation deposit scheme. I want to say on behalf of the Opposition that IEDs were never introduced to be a form of tax evasion. Our shadow Treasurer has said that some tax leakage did occur, but the removal of in-out averaging effectively eliminated that tax leakage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Say that again.

—For the benefit of the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), I will repeat it: The removal of in-out averaging effectively removed that tax leakage. This afternoon I ask the House: What do IEDs do? The income equalisation deposit scheme provides primary producers with an opportunity to level out their tax bill. It ensures that the tax burden which a primary producer faces is not more than it would be if he had a steady income. Some people might say that tax averaging does the same thing. I would agree; so it does, but tax averaging does it for a period of three years and farms and seasons, sadly, do not work to three-year cycles. Averaging allows a farmer to average his past income. IEDs allow a farmer to anticipate what his future income will be and so manage his economy to accommodate what he expects to happen in the future. With IEDs farmers endeavour to take some of the unpredictability out of farm cash flows. IEDs place real demands on farmers for responsible management decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: It is essential that the income equalisation deposit scheme should contain some incentives for farmers to want to use it. The old scheme provided such incentives. It is true that the scheme needed some modification. We agreed with that earlier this afternoon. The changes which the Government proposes to make to the scheme destroy those incentives. The new scheme has been in existence since May last year. What has happened since then? Subscriptions to IEDs have gone from $160m to $3m. What does that tell us about the new scheme? The reality is that the last drought cost the Government $300m, but what did it cost the farmers, the country people, of Australia? The figure is inestimable. The sobering thought for this House is: What would be the cost of a drought today without the IED resource that was available to help farmers through the last drought? The old scheme was designed to allow prudent farmers to make provision for future eccentricities in farm management.

I turn my attention for a moment to the comments made by the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby). Sadly, the honourable member gave only qualified support to the impact of the farm sector on the current economic recovery. The honourable member was not gracious enough to acknowledge the impact, for example , of the wages pause on the present economic recovery; nor did he trouble to acknowledge the snowballing impact the farm sector has on the Austrlaian economy . He did say that there had been a 20 per cent rise in tractor sales. What does he imagine is the impact of that rise in tractor sales and the rise involved in what farmers are spending on fences, chemicals, and sundry and assorted farm improvements on the Australian economy? Farming is known as primary industry. It is primary industry because what happens to it affects the rest of the Australian economy. For that reason, the rest of the economy is known as secondary industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is still the biggest exporter.

—The honourable member is quite right; it is still the largest exporter. The honourable member for Bendigo went on to say that the old scheme was used for tax strategy. The Opposition has no qualms about that. That is what the old scheme was designed for; not for tax avoidance but for tax strategy. Is the honourable member for Bendigo against big wheat farmers? Does he not want there to be any export? The scheme was designed to aid major exporters in Australia to continue to be viable primary producers. The whole purpose of the old scheme was better cash management. The impression I gained, sadly, from members of the Government this afternoon in the debate was that they were trying to say that the farmers of Australia, as a result of the drought, have suddenly become the wealthiest people in Australia. What I and members on this side of the House know is that in reality farmers are frequently cash poor.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) said that there was no money available for IEDs, largely taking up the thrust of my argument. The honourable member was right. But that is no excuse for ruining a scheme that works for those farmers who need to use it. Does the honourable member want all farmers to be too poor to use IEDs? Would it not be better to look at those farmers who are currently not generating the income that allows them to use IEDs to see what we can do to aid them to move into a higher income bracket? What would have happened to the Hawke recovery if it were not for those productive farmers who have been a part of the national recovery? Has the Government opposite forgotten that only the wheat and grain growers have seen an increase in real income? And that has been as a result of the increase in tonnage delivered, not price per tonne, as I said earlier. Has the Government forgotten that early this year the Bureau of Agricultural Economics forecast that the farm income per man/year on horticultural farms would decrease from $1,596 in 1982-83 to $740 in 1983-84?

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that per farm?

—Yes. This reflects, of course, also on the diary industry and on other rural industries. The honourable member for Bendigo and the honourable member for Eden Monaro were anxious to tell us that only 6 or 7 per cent of farmers used the old scheme. That is perfectly true. Only 8 per cent of farmers used the old scheme because the rest of them were damn near broke. They were damn near broke as a result of the drought. What they need-and needed-are not poorly structured IED alternatives but responsible economic management.

SPEECH.PARA: They needed a government prepared to honour its promise when it said there would be no wine tax, prepared to honour the fact that fuel excises ought to be indexed, prepared to make satisfactory trading arrangements for beef and citrus industries, prepared to fight the 14 per cent wage claim that Australian rural industry currently faces, prepared to make a real commitment to smaller government and not go about the irrational expansion of Parliament that we are about to see, prepared to extend the Fraser Government's wage pause and prepared to tone down some of the arrogance of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that has made it so difficult for us on this side of the House to make real political points.

The change to the legislation does nothing to redress real farm difficulties. An unreal demand is now made on farmers to forecast their income. Under this legislation there is the threat of imprisonment if they fail, 12 months in advance, accurately to guess what their income will be given the vagaries of the weather, export markets, exchange rates, government action and bond rates. What the farmers of this nation would welcome, rather than the emasculation of the IED scheme, is some positive action, some assurance that this Government will impose no capital tax or death duties, no assets test on farmers and the reintroduction of the Fraser Government's water resource program.

The honourable member for Wannon has rightly pointed out that the new proposals introduce an element of inflexibility into the IED scheme. IEDs were designed to be a tool for farmers to use to enable them to pay the same amount of tax as would apply if their income had been spread over a vast number of years. I support the amendment moved by the shadow Treasurer to help to keep income equalisation deposits as effective management tools for Australian farmers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse totally the remarks by my colleague the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), who has just resumed his seat. Having heard something of the earlier debate on this subject, I commend those who look towards the income equalisation deposit scheme as a way by which farmers can better manage their agricultural enterprises. I want to comment on a number of aspects of the change but I think philosophically the first and most important part of this legislation that all Australians should register is that for reasons that we see related to the Government's philosophy, it progressively is removing the opportunity for individuals in this society to take steps to care for themselves and to preserve the standard of living they wish to have on retirement.

SPEECH.PARA: We had a debate earlier today on the general subject of what will happen when an assets test is introduced affecting pensioners. We know that the scheme that had been in place over many years under successive coalition governments was designed to ensure that those who are in the retirement bracket are in a position where they can help through their own savings to preserve a standard of living. In the changes we introduced to remove the assets test on the assessment of pension entitlement we recognised that people did not always want to dispose of their assets. But what we are talking about here relates very much to the sorts of incentives we sought to provide in the pension area, only in this instance to the rural sector. In the pension area we sought to provide an opportunity for people to provide during their working lives for their retirements. In this income equalisation deposit area we sought to provide an opportunity for people in the rural sector to set aside funds in good years so that they would be better able to care for their farming operation when any form of natural disaster hit. That was the whole purpose of the scheme I set down when first introducing the legislation in 1976 as Minister for Primary Industry.

I think it is worth commenting that at that time there were two prime aspects to the legislation. The legislation now before the House removes altogether the advantages that were in the old legislation and, supposedly on the bandwagon of trying to avoid some type of tax manipulation, we have, as has been described in a paper prepared by a member of the Australian Rural Adjustment Unit in the University of New England, made a regressive move. The paper states that the scheme represented by this legislation:
. . . constitutes a backward step in agricultural policy-making. It is one which does not take full cognisance of the problems associated with farm income instability in this country.

Sadly, the scheme had not been in place long enough before all these dramatic changes were introduced to it. We had two changes. I think many honourable members on this side of the House could have worn the IED changes proposed in May 1983 but the changes now proposed, in my view, put the scheme back in the same category as the earlier drought bonds proposal which all of us felt was inadequate.

People need to remember that there are several elements affecting agriculture. The honourable member for Wakefield has just referred to one of them; that is, the fluctuating seasons. Those of us from rural electorates know how diabolically the drought of the last three to four years affected rural incomes. It did not only affect rural incomes; it also contributed to unemployment and the decline in income and employment opportunities generally right throughout this nation. Indeed, it was the breaking of the drought more than any other single factor that led to the economic recovery over the last 12 months. The IEDs were intended to minimise the need on future occasions for governments to provide the back-up to the rural community to offset the effect of drought. They were designed to help not only in drought but also in all other forms of natural disaster. While the withdrawal proposals are there in this legislation, the whole concept was to try to even out the fluctuations of income and to provide an offset which the farmer himself could initiate against the disasters which affect so many areas.

We tried in the past to devise some form of insurance. The honourable member for Wakefield spoke about the problems in the horticultural industries. There are many industries in which, for example, there might be a propensity to storm damage and in which any type of crop insurance is available only at a very high premium at an almost prohibitive level. We sought in the area of IEDs to give an alternative, whether for horticultural crops, the pastoral industry or the farming industry. We sought to provide an income equalisation deposit scheme as a means by which the farmer at a time when he had a high income would be given an incentive to put funds aside. By removing the tax incentive the whole concept of IEDs is changed. What I see as happening at the moment is that the Government is providing not much more than an interest-bearing deposit. With all this heigh -ho about the interest rate that is payable, the Government is not providing the incentive that a meaningful IED scheme should contain.

We were after the two concepts-a real incentive to avoid fluctuation of income and a real incentive to try to ensure income tax equality with other sectors of the community. Without going over that income tax argument, we need to remember that at the time of my introduction of this legislation we also made significant changes to tax averaging which were designed to provide for farmers something like equality of tax opportunity with other members of the community.

This Government, far from providing tax equality, is not only removing this part of that package but also providing for anybody whose income under the average scheme falls below the threshold to pay tax. As I understand it, the farmer is now called upon to pay tax only where his tax in any one year under the averages scheme falls below the tax threshold. His option, under the schemes introduced by the Government, is to pull out of averaging.That will remove the option of coming back into averaging. The consequence is he loses. It is a catch -22 situation; he loses whichever way he goes. In nothing of what I am saying am I contending that proper action against any sort of tax avoidance scheme should not be taken by government. Indeed, one of the reasons why tax minimisation is indulged in so much less frequently today than it was in past years-my colleague the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has frequently come into this place and pointed this out-is the many steps we took. It is not because of steps that this Government has taken. Indeed, for all this Government's rhetoric, it has been notably short in legislation to reduce tax avoidance. So nothing of what I am saying with respect to this legislation is intended to condone tax avoidance. I totally accept measures that are intended to reduce steps in that direction.

The whole IED scheme is not there as a tax avoidance mechanism. It is there because the tax incentive is the only way, in a time of high income, that farmers will be encouraged to deposit reasonable sums of money. Regrettably the Government has not even realised the total package that was there. I have mentioned tax averaging and IEDs, but when we introduced the scheme it was linked with the Primary Industry Bank of Australia. This Government has now provided a subsidy for PIBA to try to ensure that it can provide long term loans . At the time the Primary Industry Bank of Australia began operations the average term of lending for farmers was about four years. Some, if they were lucky, might have got about six years. As a result of the introduction of IEDs it was possible to provide some funds, from the moneys that were deposited as income equalisation deposits, to the Primary Industry Bank to enable the term of loans to be extended. Whatever people argue about PIBA, the catalyst that its long term loans provided spread throughout the rest of the trading banks and suddenly we found trading banks saying to their customers: 'Look, perhaps we can provide you with a longer term loan than the one you have'.

If honourable members want to know why we wanted longer term loans, let me explain. Behind the philosophy of the National Party of Australia and the Liberal Party of Australia is the concept of the family farmer. If we are to preserve the family farmer we have to provide the opportunity for a young person who goes on the land, who sets up his business, to have a reasonable chance of repayment of the very large sums of capital now required over the term of his operation of that property. If we do not provide the incentives for him to retain some funds when he has a good crop he pays the money out in tax. The result of that is that when there is a natural disaster-a drought, a flood or a bushfire-he puts out his hand to get help from the Government or, frankly, he is just unable to operate and is forced to sell out his property.

Any type of drought insurance will not work, in my view, unless it is linked to some form of tax incentive-unless it is there with a low interest scheme. I have not been one of those who believe it is necessary to provide a premium interest rate to attract people into this sort of scheme. In the past under the drought bond scheme it was not the interest that proved to be the inducement necessary to provide that insulation against fluctuating incomes and drought. The sad thing was that, whilst IEDs were introduced in 1976, the run of seasons had not been sufficiently beneficial for enough funds to be put into them. In spite of that, many millions of dollars were invested from IED funds in PIBA. For many people it represented a very worthwhile way to offset their incomes.

Sure, there might have been abuses. I know that some people have looked at the tax avoidance mechanism and complained about it. Others have said that it provided for the wealthy and not for the poorer farmer, but it did provide for the family farmer. It there were changes needed to this scheme they are not the changes represented by this September package which is now being transmitted into legislation. I am afraid that what we are seeing is but another attack by this Government on the two keys of success of Australia: One is personal endeavour and the other is family operation. The thrust against personal endeavour is that this scheme is designed to ensure that the average fellow will not understand the scheme. It is just another interest bearing deposit. It is not a scheme that is going to be sufficiently attractive for the small farmer even to get the value out of it when he has a good season.

The thrust against the family farmer is that unless there is an inducement of this sort more and more family farmers will be dependent on hand-outs from government when the natural disasters come. We will find that their tax liabilities are higher than they can afford and there will be an accelerating trend away from that key element of agriculture in Australia which has been so important in establishing the rural industries in this nation, which are so important to the whole maintenance and development of the Australian economy. I very much regret that the Government is changing such a worthwhile scheme in such a regressive manner.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all honourable members who have taken part in this debate on the Loan (Income Equalization Deposits) Amendment Bill. I particularly thank the Opposition for its co-operation in reducing the number of speakers who have taken part in this debate. I accept there were many other honourable members on the other side who would have liked to have been involved in the debate, just as there were on this side. I also thank those honourable members who have cut short their speeches in order to accommodate more honourable members taking part . I regret I have not been able to be present throughout the debate, but I have received reports from senior officers of both the Department of the Treasury and the Australian Taxation Office about the arguments that have been presented.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all I want to clear up one piece of misinformation which I believe is probably the genesis of this amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill that we are dealing with this evening. That misinformation relates to the amount of funds that are at present involved in the income equalisation deposits scheme. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), in moving the Opposition's amendment-I cannot believe that the person who presented these figures to him did not do so mischieviously-said, if I have the report correctly , that the amounts involved had reduced from $160m to $3m. Does he confirm that those are the figures on which he based his argument?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the figure, yes.

—For the sake of the House being well informed on this matter, let me run through what the actual levels of IEDs have been. At 30 June 1977 the level was $37m, at 30 June 1978 it was $67m, at 30 June 1979 it was $79m, at 30 June 1980 it was $136m, at 30 June 1981 it was $163m, at 30 June 1982 it was $166m, at 30 June 1983 it was $155m and at 31 March 1984 it was $135m. There are two interesting factors there. One is that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has been misinformed. I cannot think how that has happened, but he has been. The second very important factor to note is that the level of deposits started to decline well before the introduction of the new scheme, or the doing away with the tax advantages in relation to the old scheme. The fact that we all know is that the new scheme virtually came into effect on 1 September 1983 and not in May 1983, when the figures started to decline.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw the attention of the House again to the fact that, whereas the level of deposits at 30 June 1982 was $166m, by 30 June 1983-two months before any changes were made-there had already been a reduction. Of course there was a reduction in the level of deposits because of the cycle relating to the drought. That is why the level of the deposits has now gone down further to $135m. That is the whole purpose of the scheme-for that withdrawal to take place in poor times. I have great confidence that this scheme is sufficiently attractive to fulfil the purposes that have been very eloquently outlined from both sides of the House. We are very anxious to help the farming community, just as the Opposition is.

Most of these points have already been made by my colleagues the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby), the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) and the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) and in my second reading speech. In all those cases the Government's position has been set out clearly. We are anxious to assist the farming community, but we do not favour leaving benefits to the whim of this tax scale, particularly when it allows loopholes for tax minimisation schemes. The Leader of the National Party (Mr Sinclair) was gracious enough in what was otherwise a pretty ungracious speech to agree that this scheme had allowed loopholes in that tax minimisation schemes were being used.

The Government is determined to stamp out all those sorts of loopholes. This is one of the reasons why the changes have been made. I repeat: We do favour income equalisation deposits. This is what the new IED scheme is about as well. We do favour schemes that are of benefit to all income groups, not just the tall poppies, and that is what this IED scheme is about too. The previous scheme gave most of the benefits to those on higher incomes. Labor's scheme benefits all. With the previous scheme the higher the tax rate one paid, of course, the more benefit one got. With our scheme people, whether big or small, will get benefits . It is a genuine income equalisation scheme.

The points I have made are not just political rhetoric. We have had enough of that in the debate. Before resuming my seat-I know I must not take much time as many other members had to cut short their speeches-I want to quote from a letter dated 27 May 1983 from the former Deputy Director of the National Farmers Federation, which he sent to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). This letter is one of the reasons why we decided there was need for such changes to the scheme. In the course of the letter, the then Deputy Director, Mr David Trebeck said:
I believe it would be far simpler to have investment in IED's at the determined interest rate without the complicating or contrived trappings of either 'tax credits' or returned cheques.

That statement comes from somebody who is not making political rhetoric. It comes from the former Deputy Director of none other than the National Farmers Federation. When we in this Government, who are anxious to help the farming community, receive a letter to that effect we act accordingly, and this letter was one of the reasons why we have so acted. The Opposition's amendment does nothing more than return to the bad old days. The existing scheme is not a scheme which would be without its difficulties and it allows loopholes for tax minimisation. We will not allow that to happen. That is why we have made these changes. I urge the House not only to oppose the amendment but also to support this very worthwhile Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House has a general debate covering this Bill and the Dividend Recoupment Tax Bill 1983 [No. 2] as they are related measures.
