TALK.START.PARA: —In the continuing struggle by the people of Chile against the repressive Pinochet regime, the women of Chile play a vital and courageous role and I am proud to place on the record of the Parliament of Australia tonight a letter sent from the women of Chile to their Australian sisters and to the people of Australia. It was presented to the Australian Ambassador on 22 March, and says:

SPEECH.PARA: Through your means we want to bring to the attention of women of Australia and your country's public opinion in general, the plight of women and of the people of Chile. We deem it necessary to do so as part of our struggle for life in our country.

Who are we? We are Chilean women from many different sectors, professional and blue-collar workers, students and peasants, artist and homemakers; women of all ages who have survived more than a decade of a deadly government system whose clearest signs have been assassinations, exile, disappearances, secret jails, torture, banishment, repression of dissidents and all kinds of power abuse and arbitrary actions which hit the poorest sectors of the population.

We accuse the military regime of plunging our country into the most serious crisis in history, an overall crisis which goes beyond the political, economic and social crisis. In this crisis, the future and the life of our nation are at stake. We live in a generalized atmosphere of violence, of growing poverty and unemployment; there are hundreds of thousands of youths without any hope whatsoever in the future. This hopelessness turns many youths to drugs and prostitution, often at a very early age. All this explains our feeling of urgency when we fear for our fate as a people. We seek a future where life might have a chance.

We women have therefore declared a permanent state of mobilization, in order to confront what we consider is an inhumane government. We are not just women in pain, complaining about our country's tragedy. Last December, twelve thousand women met here in Santiago and made a pledge to struggle for life in Chile and to keep up this struggle until we put an end to this deadly regime.

The month of March was declared 'Women's Month' and we made several peaceful demonstrations to publicize our purpose. On March 8 we suffered the government's repression: 33 women were arrested; 9 union leaders were held without charge for 5 days at the order of the Ministry of the Interior and one of them suffered an abortion as a result of this ordeal. Gross mistreatment by the police force was denounced in several cases.

The brutality of government repression has made it impossible to carry out other activities destined to denounce the violation of human rights, in general, and women's rights, in particular. Thus we decided to culminate this 'Women's Month', addressing the women and the people of the world. Because what happens to the people of one country also affects the people of all other countries. It is to the conscience of Humanity-and to each man and woman-that we turn to denounce these crimes. Silence and indifference only condone these criminal deeds.

In a few days-on March 27-there will be another Day of National Protest in which women will participate actively. We remind world public opinion of the recent massacre which took place in Chile on August 11, 1983, when 18,000 soldiers occupied the city of Santiago and there were 82 dead and hundreds of injured. Justice has not yet been done.

We know that those of us in Chile who want to put an end to this rule of death are a majority. We feel strengthened by both reason and morality in our struggle against the force of weapons, of greed and petty interests. We know that difficult and painful times are ahead in our struggle for life and democracy. We are, however, willing to run risks because that is what our conscience dictates.

We know also that the women of the world will understand us and that they would be willing to do the same: to struggle to regain freedom and leave the legacy of a decent country to our children and grandchildren.
I place that letter on record in solidarity with my sisters in Chile.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Airline Employees: Reduced Air Fare Benefits

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mountford Mr J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 14 September 1983 :

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that employees and their relatives of Qantas and TAA are entitled to reduced air fare benefits both within Australia and overseas; if so, (a) what are the benefits available, (b) how frequently are they available, (c) what sum was foregone by each airline during the 1982-83 financial year and (d) is it a condition of employment that such benefits are made available.
(2) Can he say whether similar benefits are available to employees and their relatives of Ansett and other local airlines.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I have been advised by TAA and Qantas that concessions for domestic and international travel are offered to all employees and their close relatives.

(a) The level of benefits provided by Qantas varies according to an employee's length of service. All categories of staff concessional travel are subject to space being available after all commercial requirements are met.

The benefits available on TAA services are similarly dependent on the number of years of service and are available to the employee and spouse. Benefits on overseas airlines arise from reciprocal agreement with individual airlines.
(b) The frequency with which these benefits are made available by Qantas is dependent upon an employee's length of service and the destination.

For employees of TAA, concessional travel is unlimited on an unbooked basis- travel available only when space available. Concessional travel with the benefit of a booking is restricted to a limited number of off peak flights which are continualy reviewed to ensure changes in passenger booking requirements are not compromised by staff concession travel.

(c) Qantas has advised that because all staff concessional travel on Qantas is subject to commercial requirements, revenues are not foregone. In 1982-83 Qantas fully recovered the administrative costs and the additional out of pocket expenses generated by concessional travel. I am advised that in 1982-83 the Qantas concessional travel scheme yielded approximately $3.3m after deducting the expenses itemised above.

TAA has advised that the estimated revenue from staff concession travel availed on TAA services for financial year 1982-83 is $4.3m. Rather than revenue being foregone, TAA advises there is a contribution to overheads, since in the majority of cases staff travel is on a space available basis so that seats are not taken from full fare paying passengers.
(d) Staff concession travel is an employee benefit and not a condition of employment.

(2) While I am aware that Ansett together with other domestic airlines and operators generally provide travel benefits to their staff, I do not have details of the conditions or the extent of travel allowed under these concessional arrangements.
